Traffic Counts

Every day, MDOT is in contact with over 1,000 law enforcement agencies across the state to obtain information on motor vehicle crashes, and in an effort to be up to date with the latest information, a computerized system was developed to track traffic data. This system, called Automated Violation Reporting (AVR), is based on real-time data collected from more than 10,000 miles of roadway, and has been in use since the mid-1990s. During the winter months, there is a reduction in snowplow operations, which results in an increase in the number of vehicles on the road. This in turn leads to an increase in the number of traffic violators who are ticketed and impounded. By adding this data to the AVR system, MDOT is able to make more accurate estimates of VMT and its impact on air quality.

In 1963, construction began on a two-lane (I-5) freeway through the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains. Highway officials were keen to avoid what they saw as the problem of overcrowding on the Los Angeles River Freeway, which was in the middle of construction at the time. By the time the freeway was completed in 1964, the L.A. River Freeway had grown to its current length of more than six miles. As a result, the California Highways and Transportation Commission (CHTTC) began looking for ways to relieve traffic congestion on the heavily clogged freeway. One of the options was to reroute the freeway in the direction of Hesperia.

According to Caltrans documents, the decision was made to realign the freeway east of El Sereno and west of Pico Blanco "to provide a route for motor vehicular traffic that bypasses the congested and overburdened section of the Santa Susana Pass." CHTTC engineer J.E. Main article: List of Shikamaru's personality traits

Shikamaru is known for his stoic demeanour, rarely showing emotion other than when he is on the verge of losing his sense of self. He does not like to be told what to do, preferring to do what he pleases without questioning his superiors in the first place. As a result, he has no qualms about killing his team-mates under duress, such as Gaara in the anime, Kankurō in the manga, and Tenten in the video games. This is in contrast to the genin of Konoha, who are taught to respect their teammates and work together to achieve a common goal. Despite this, Shikamaru tends to make light of his teammates' misfortunes, which results in them feeling a sense of inadequacy and low self-esteem. On the other hand, he cares deeply for his friends and will go to great lengths to protect them, even if it means getting himself killed along the way. It is unknown what motivates him to carry out assassinations, but one thing is for certain: he is not one to back down from a fight no matter how dire the situation.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Meridian was a small village at the start of the American Civil War in 1861. Its strategic position at the railroad junction led to the Confederate construction of several military
reference_text: installations to support the war. During the Battle of Meridian in 1864, General William Tecumseh Sherman led troops into the city, destroying the railroads in every direction, as well as an arsenal and immense storehouses ; his forces burned much of the buildings to the ground. Sherman is reported to have said afterwards, " Meridian, with its depots, store @-@ houses, arsenal, hospitals, offices, hotels, and cantonments no longer exists. " Despite the destruction, the railroad lines in the city were rapidly repaired, back in operation 26 working days after the battle. Race relations remained tense during the Reconstruction era, with the riot of 1871 following a fire that damaged many businesses.

Meridian was home to a Methodist church, a post office, and a saloon. There was also a general store run by Union sympathizers. This store sold foodstuffs and medical supplies to the war effort. On the night of April 12, 1861, an order was issued to fire on the townspeople, resulting in the deaths of at least thirty-five people. One of the dead was Dr. J. C. Brown, a well-known physician who was in Meridian to perform surgery on a wounded Union soldier. His body was dragged through the streets for three or four miles before it was buried in a gravesite next to the town hall.


The Battle of Meridian was the first skirmish of the Civil War. It took place on April 12, 1861, a little more than a month after the Emancipation Proclamation went into effect. In 1864, President Abraham Lincoln signed the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, emancipating slaves in the District of Columbia. This brought an end to the secession of the D.C. slave population and paved the way for the reunification of the nation.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> During the American Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s, Meridian was home to a Council of Federated Organizations ( COFO ) office and several other activist organizations
reference_text: . James Chaney and other local residents, along with Michael Schwerner, his wife Rita, and Andrew Goodman, volunteers from the North, worked to create a community center, holding classes to help prepare African Americans in the area to regain the power to vote. Whites in the area resented the activism, and racial tension often resulted in violence. In June 1964, Chaney, Schwerner, and Goodman went to Neshoba County, Mississippi, to meet with members of a black church that had been bombed and burned. The three disappeared that night on their way back to Meridian. Following a massive FBI investigation, their murdered bodies were found two months later, buried in an earthen dam.

Meridian's African American population swelled during the Jim Crow era, reaching 2,000 in 1960. That number dwindled to less than a hundred by the mid-1970s, but was on the rise again by the time Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in 1968. At the time, Meridian was an all-white city, but over the next 30 years, the city began to diversify in ways that would become emblematic of the city's transformation.

On this day, we remember the life and legacy of Medgar Evers, a civil rights activist who was killed in Jackson, Mississippi, on April 4, 1963. Evers fought for desegregation in Meridian, and helped spearhead the march from Meridian to Selma, Alabama, that led to the passage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. More than four decades later, his death remains a rallying cry for those who seek to end racial inequities in the United States.

A decade later, the population shrank to less than half that (400,000) and remained in that range for the next 30 years. That's when San Francisco began to lose its mojo as a place to live, said Paul Rose, who grew up in the city and taught at U.C. Berkeley until his retirement in the 1990s.

"There was a time when people moved here for the water, which was good," Rose said. "But over the years, that stopped being the case."

Rent Control Restricts Demographics The most obvious way that rent control limits the supply of housing is by raising the price of housing. For example, California Proposition 13, passed in 1978, requires developers to set aside a certain percentage of units for low-income families. This has the effect of creating a de facto rent control, since the market does not work in the long run as it does in other states. As a result, prices go up, even during recessions. When housing prices are high, it is harder for people to afford living in San Francisco. This, in turn, discourages people from moving here in the first place. Historical Significance

The Civil War was fought in Meridian, and one of the bloodiest battles of the war was fought on the Battle of Meridian. Confederate General Jubal Early was attempting to break through the Union lines by launching a surprise attack on the Union encampment at Cedar Creek. In the confusion, an artillery shell went off and mortally wounded Early. His body was taken back to Fort Pillow, and a funeral was held to honor the fallen general. This resulted in the firing of the city's first salvo of musket volleys, which is commemorated every July 4th and has been a tradition since at least the 19th century.

It was during the Civil War that Meridian began to grow at a rapid pace. Many businesses were established, and the population boomed to its current size of more than 200,000. This growth spurt was the result of the railroad that was built to connect Meridian to the Gulf

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Meridian is rightly considered an architectural treasure trove being one the nations most intact cities from the turn of the last century. Architecture students from around the nation and Canada
reference_text: are known to visit Meridian in groups as part of their coursework due to numerous structures in the city having been designed by noted architects. The only home in the US south designed by noted Canadian born Architect Louis S. Curtiss, famous for inventing the glass curtain wall skyscraper, is extant on Highland Park. The Frank Fort designed Threefoot Building is generally considered one of the best Art Deco skyscrapers in the US and is often compared to Detroit's famed Fisher Building. Noted California Architect Wallace Neff designed a number of homes in Meridian as well as in the Alabama Black Belt which adjoins the city across the nearby Alabama State line. He had relatives in Meridian and Selma who were executives in the then thriving railroad industry and would take commissions in the area when commissions in California were lean. His work is mostly concentrated in the lower numbered blocks of Poplar Springs Drive where his 2516 Poplar Springs Drive is often compared to the similarly designed Falcon Lair, the Beverly Hills home in Benedict Canyon of Rudolph Valentino. One Neff work was lost to an expansion of Anderson Hospital in 1990 and another in Marion Park burned in the 1950s. The Meridian Post Office with its interior done entirely of bronze and Verde marble is also noteworthy as a very fine example of the type of Post Office structures built in thriving and well to do cities in the 1920s and originally had Lalique lighting which was removed sadly during a 1960s remodeling and which are now in private residences on Poplar Springs Drive and in North Hills.

Obesity is linked to a higher risk of depression, but the link is not as strong as previously thought, a study suggests.

Researchers from King's College London looked at data from 4,636 people who took part in the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPAC).

Health experts said it was "encouraging" to see a link between body mass index (BMI) and depression.

The study, published in the Annals of Internal Medicine, is the largest of its kind to date.

Rodgers was born in St. Louis, Missouri on this day in 1887. He grew up in Glen Ellyn, Illinois and earned a GED in high school. As a teenager, Rodgers played banjo and fiddle in the band known as J.A. Rodgers and the Stragglers. At the age of twenty-one, Rodgers moved to Los Angeles to pursue a career in music. After a few years of trying to make a living as a songwriter, Rodgers decided to change his career and focus on his guitar playing. This was the beginning of something that would revolutionize the music industry by the mid-1920s. The following year, Rodgers signed a contract with Chess Records and began recording his first number one hit, "You're a Big Girl Now." By the time Rodgers hit his thirtieth birthday, he had sold over 100 million records to date. It was an incredible feat for a 19-year-old, but Rodgers was undeterred by the accolades and continued to put out hit after hit. One of Rodgers' most famous songs, "My Sharona," was written by his wife, Doris, and the rest is history. Rodgers passed away from bronchitis on his seventy-eighth birthday in January of 1950. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Meridian is served by the Meridian @-@ Lauderdale County Public Library, located at the corner of 7th Street and 26th Avenue. The city originally had
reference_text: two Carnegie libraries, both built in 1913 – one for blacks and one for whites. A group of women had formed the Fortnightly Book and Magazine Club in the 1880s and began raising money to build a library for the city. The books they collected and shared within the club were later the basis of the library collection for Meridian. With wide support for the library, the club enlisted Israel Marks, a city leader, to approach the national philanthropist Andrew Carnegie for funding assistance. The library for blacks was built at 13th Street and 28th Avenue on land donated by St. Paul Methodist Church, and the library for whites was established in a building originally owned by members of the First Presbyterian Church of Meridian, who sold it to the city on September 25, 1911. The African American library was the only library for blacks in the state until after World War I and is the only Carnegie library ever built for African Americans in the country. The two libraries served the city until 1967, when the institutions became integrated because of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, combined their collections, and moved all materials to their current location. The former white library was renovated and converted into the Meridian Museum of Art in 1970, and the former African @-@ American library was demolished on May 28, 2008.

I know it's hard to believe, but one of the most beautiful places in the world is under my feet. That's right, you read that right. Just a few years ago, we were having a cup of tea and reading a guidebook to Borneo, when the thought occurred to me: how on earth am I going to get there? There was no bus, no ferries, no motorbikes on the roads that criss-cross the archipelago from Sumatra to Aceh, let alone anything that could take me the 1,000km or so to Batam, the gateway to the Srivijaya National Park. In an uncharacteristic moment of lucidity, I looked up the cost of a round-trip flight from Heathrow to Medan, which at the time was more than £500. My family and I packed our bags and hit the road.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The island is composed of a variety of volcanic and sedimentary rock formations from the Devonian period. At that time the Scottish landmass formed part of the
reference_text: Old Red Sandstone Continent and lay some 10 @-@ 25 degrees south of the equator. The accumulations of Old Red Sandstone, laid down from 408 to 370 million years ago, were created as earlier Silurian rocks, uplifted by the formation of Pangaea, eroded and then were deposited into river deltas. The freshwater Lake Orcadie existed on the edges of the eroding mountains, stretching from Shetland to the southern Moray Firth. The structure of Papa Stour is largely made up of ashes and lavas from volcanic activity associated with this period, including bands of solidified volcanic ash and lava ( rhyolite ), but there is also a Devonian fish bed at Lamba Banks. There are numerous large boulders deposited by Pleistocene glaciation.

Geology [ edit ]

Isle of Skye in 1859

The island is one of the most seismically active areas in the UK, with over 1,000 earthquakes recorded in the last 100 years. There are two caldera-forming basins on the island, which are thought to have formed as magma intruded into the subduction zone that underlies the island. This process is the same as that which formed the craters on the South Orkney archipelago.[1]

Climatic conditions [ edit ]

Iceland is a temperate island, with a subtropical climate that is characterised by long, wintry winters and warm, humid summers. Glaciers and glacial cirques are common in the north and north-flurries occur sporadically in the south. Rainfall is less than one-tenth of the UK average, and the average annual temperature is 9°C (48°F). Temperatures can fluctuate by as much as +1°C (32°F) in the summer and -1°C (32°F) in the winter. Summer sea breezes are a common feature of the island, and wind chills can reach minus 40°C (minus 50°F). Snow is the most common precipitation on the island,

There is a circle of stones near the beach at Housa Voe, which are the remains of a'ting ', or local assembly. ( The story of his unfortunate daughter is referred to above. ) The remains of Duke Hakon's thirteenth @-@ century house are still visible near Housa Voe.

Archaeologists excavating the site last year found a pottery sherd dating to the 13th century A.D. This may be the oldest Viking artefact in the world.

Papa Stour was an important stop on the Anglo-Saxon voyages to the Faroes, and has been home to archaeological excavations since the 1960s. There are over 1,000 burials at the site, as well as evidence of trade and social interaction between Scandinavians and Norwegians for hundreds of years.

Read more about the excavation here. You can get a sense of the Vikings' approach to land ownership by looking at this map of Viking settlements based on information from the sagas. Click on the image to enlarge it.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Aberdeen trawler Ben Doran A178, foundered on the Ve Skerries 3 miles northwest of Papa Stour, on the evening of
reference_text: 28 March 1930 while on her way to the village of Scalloway to land her catch. When she grounded weather conditions were fairly good but it was not until the following day that a passing trawler saw, and reported the wreck. By the time that various rescue attempts were launched by the coastguard and local volunteers ( there being no lifeboat in Shetland at that time ), weather conditions had deteriorated to the point where it was impossible to approach the skerries. A request had been made for the Stromness lifeboat from Orkney, only 120 miles away, to launch, but the request was made too late to be of help. All 9 crew perished in the wreck. Only 3 bodies were recovered, that of James Mitchell, which was returned to Aberdeen, and the bodies of J. Cormack and J.R. Insh, which were buried in Scalloway.

An attempt was made to cut the lifelines with a harpoon, but without success. All attempts to make rescues were fruitless. He was wearing a lifejacket and his wristwatch was found to be working.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Crofting is the mainstay of island life. Sheep form the backbone of the agricultural economy but a diversity livestock are kept, including cattle, pigs,
reference_text: goats, chickens, ducks and geese. Vegetable are grown too, often in the shelter of circular walls, such plots being known as'plantie scrubs '. Fishing is still conducted but on a relatively small scale. There is a post office at the pier, but no shop. Mains electricity only came to the island at the close of the twentieth century. The Papa Stour Project is a Christian supported housing service offering accommodation to men with drug and alcohol issues. Ferries now sail across the Sound of Papa to West Burrafirth on the Shetland Mainland. The crossing takes 45 minutes, and although the Snolda carries cars, there is only one short road on the island.For visiting yachts the four main voes provide good shelter, but the strong tides in both the Sound of Papa and to the north west require considerable care.

It is hard to imagine such a diverse and well-adapted fauna in the tropics, but that is the kind of environment that thrives on low light, temperature extremes, and short days. There are no rainforests, jungles, bogs, savannas, or mangroves to muck up the water and feed the critters. All the land is arid, which means you are free to graze your livestock without worrying about overgrazing. As a result, livestock have adapted to the island by becoming omnivores, eating a wide variety of plants and invertebrates. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> " Rowin Foula doon! " refers to the fishermens'practice of rowing their open fishing boat out to sea until the high cliffs
reference_text: of Foula were no longer visible. This entailed the boat being some 96 kilometres ( 60 mi ) west of Papa Stour. The'tide @-@ lumps'are increased swells of unusual size due to the combined action of wind against tide. The resonant final image of the piece is of the fishermen being led back home to Papa by the'scent o flooers'across the water. This is an example of Vagaland's ability to create a vivid sensual impression of a situation. An extra layer of meaning is added by the knowledge that Da Horn o Papa collapsed in a storm around the time of this poem's composition, so that it is a tribute not just to a lost way of life, but a noted geographical feature.

Folklore [ edit ]

The most famous version of the rowin foula doon is the story of St. Patrick, who in the 6th century brought Christianity to Ireland. At that time, Ireland was a pagan country, and the pagans believed that the sea was the abode of demons. This belief was based on the belief that demons lived in the sea, and their dwelling place was known as the Liffey Trench. In the week prior to the trough, sea surface temperatures (SSTs) in the equatorial Pacific were anomalously warm, a departure from the climatological long-term trend. This is known as the Kelvin-Helmholtz (KH) anomaly, and it is one of the most closely scrutinized aspects of ENSO. To this day, scientists are at a loss to explain the anomaly. Some theorize that atmospheric circulation may have played a role, while others point to climate change as a possible cause.

What is known is that the KP anomaly tends to recur every 2-3 years, peaking in the summer and troughing in the winter. For the most part, the KP fluctuates between 0.5 and 1.0°C (roughly 0.5 ºF and 1 ºC in the tropics and subtropics, respectively). As far as we can tell, none of the KP anomalies have been associated with El Nino/La Nina events. That does not mean that they are not important, however. It is worth noting that the KP's history is far from clear-cut, and this lack of predictability lends itself to a high degree of uncertainty.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Most music historians date the writing of " The Bourgeois Blues " to Lead Belly's June 1937 trip to Washington, DC, when he was invited
reference_text: by the folklorist Alan Lomax to record for the Library of Congress's folk music collection. On the first night Lead Belly and his wife Martha spent in the city, they encountered racially discriminatory Jim Crow laws similar to those found in their native Louisiana : most hotels refused to rent rooms to African Americans and the few that would were either full or refused to serve him because he was with a white man ( Lomax ). Lomax, in some versions of the story described as an unnamed " white friend ", offered to let the couple stay for the night in his apartment near the Supreme Court Building. The next morning, Lead Belly awoke to Lomax arguing with his landlord about the presence of a black man, with the landlord threatening to call the police.

Taft, a Republican from Ohio, was President Franklin Delano Roosevelt's vice president from 1933 to 1945. At the time of his death in 1945, Taft was the longest-serving member of the Roosevelt Cabinet, serving two terms—twice as Treasury Secretary and once as Secretary of Veterans Affairs. In that capacity, he played a key role in the New Deal, working to reduce unemployment and provide social security for veterans.

As one of the most influential African-American politicians of the 20th century, Taft earned the nickname "Uncle Tom" for his hard-nosed approach to civil rights. After graduating from Tuskegee University in Alabama, he went to work for the Ku Klux Klan, fighting desegregation in the South. By the 1950s, many Democrats were distancing themselves from the Klan, but Taft remained a stalwart of the anti-communist movement. Starting third, he led by the fifth lap and ultimately led 82 laps, including the final 46, to win the race by eight car @-@ lengths over Bill Elliott. Richmond's health took a turn for the worse in the spring of 1988 when he suffered a ruptured spleen and blood clots in his lungs. At the time, medical experts did not know how to treat the condition, which was caused by a congenital thrombophlebitis (TCP) and left him bedridden for the next six months.

Over the years, Richmond has written a best-selling memoir, co-founded the Trevor Project, served as President Emeritus of HRC, and helped spearhead the passage of the Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act in 2009.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The terrain in the Trout Creek Mountains varies from broad, flat basins and rolling ridges to high rock escarpments cut by deep canyons.
reference_text: The canyons have steep walls with loose talus slopes at the bottoms. There are meadows around springs in the mountains, although most streams in the range do not flow year @-@ round. Major streams that flow off the north slopes of the mountains include ( from west to east ) Cottonwood Creek, Trout Creek, Willow Creek, and Whitehorse Creek. These streams all flow into endorheic basins in Harney County, Oregon. Trout Creek and Whitehorse Creek are the largest of the four. The Kings River and McDermitt Creek each drain an area on the south slopes of the Trout Creek Mountains. The Kings River begins in The Granites and flows south into Nevada, where it meets the Quinn River, which evaporates in the Black Rock Desert. McDermitt Creek begins in Oregon a few miles north of The Granites and flows generally east, crossing the Oregon – Nevada border five times before disappearing into the floor of the Quinn River Valley south of McDermitt.

There are over a dozen waterfalls to choose from, including Three Fountains, Grand Teton, Cuyamaca-Chaparral, El Dorado, Santa Ynez, Pecos, Red Bluff, and many more. You can hike, bike, snowshoe, cross-country ski, fly-fish, birdwander, rockclimb, rappel, or take a self-guided tour in the backcountry. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Trout Creek Mountains are composed mostly of basalt from a shield volcano that once stood where Steens Mountain is today. Crustal thinning and the
reference_text: Yellowstone hotspot, which was then beneath southeastern Oregon, induced eruptions from Steens and nearby vents about 17 million years ago, in the Miocene. The vents produced a series of lava flows that spread across the land now known as the Trout Creek Mountains. Eruptions from the Steens volcano lasted for about one million years, and at least 70 separate lava flows occurred. Under the resulting basalt rock lie much older metamorphic rocks that may be related to some of the Triassic age formations of the Blue Mountains in northeastern Oregon. Within these metamorphic rocks are diorite and granodiorite intrusive bodies which were presumably intruded during the Cretaceous Period.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The broad McDermitt Caldera is a prominent geologic feature in the Trout Creek Mountains. The oval @-@ shaped caldera is a collapsed
reference_text: lava dome that straddles the Oregon – Nevada border on the eastern side of the range and south of the Oregon Canyon Mountains. It is about 28 miles ( 45 km ) long and 22 miles ( 35 km ) wide. The lava dome was created by volcanic eruptions in the early Miocene. A total of five large ash flows were produced along with a large rhyolite dome structure. The caldera formed when the dome collapsed about 16 million years ago. The caldera contains significant ore deposits, and mercury and uranium have been mined at eight or more sites in and around the caldera. Other areas in the caldera were mined for ores of antimony, cesium, and lithium.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Trout Creek Mountains are semi @-@ arid because they are in the eastern rain shadow of mountain ranges to the west. When moist air from the
reference_text: Pacific Ocean moves eastward over the Oregon and California coastal ranges and the Cascade Range, most precipitation falls in those mountains before reaching the Trout Creek Mountains. As a result, the average annual precipitation in the Trout Creek Mountains is only 8 to 26 inches ( 200 to 660 mm ) per year, with most areas receiving between 8 and 12 inches ( 200 and 300 mm ) annually. Much of the annual precipitation occurs between the beginning of March and the end of June. Most of the rest falls as snow during the fall and winter months. Snowpack at elevations below 6 @,@ 000 feet ( 1 @,@ 800 m ) usually melts by April ; however, at the higher elevations, snow can remain until mid @-@ June. Local flooding often occurs in the spring as the snowpack melts.

generated_result.0:
tropics descends on the Rocky Mountains, it cools the air by convection (i.e. conduction) and warms it by radiation (i.e. radiation by conduction). This radiative cooling and warming is responsible for the temperature gradients that we see in the Trout Creek Mountains.

There are a number of theories as to why the trout and elk migrations take place in the winter and early spring. One of the most popular theories is that the snowmelt evaporates to form cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) which precipitate a layer of water droplets on the ground. The evaporation of the snowmelt results in a drop in temperature of 2-3 degrees Centigrade (Celcius). This drop in temperature acts as a thermostat to regulate the growth of leafy vegetation and, in turn, the food supply for the herbivores. As the temperature drops, the plants wilt and go dormant, providing a time of dormancy for the herbivores. By the time the sun comes up in the spring, the ground is covered with grasses and sedges (primarily clover and vetch) which are ready to germinate and sprout from the seedpods. It is during this time that the elk and trout make their way to the water's edge to forage for food.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Less than one percent of the range consists of meadow wetlands and riparian greenways ( vegetation along stream banks ). However, these areas are vital to
reference_text: the local ecosystem. The meadows surround springs, which are mostly on gently sloping uplands or in stream bottoms, and range in size from about 1 to 5 acres ( 0 @.@ 40 to 2 @.@ 02 ha ). Narrow riparian greenways follow the year @-@ round streams. Many greenway areas have quaking aspen and willow groves. Cottonwood and alder groves can be found at lower elevations where terrain is flatter and stream channels are wider. Sedges and rushes are also native to these stream bottoms. Years of heavy livestock grazing in parts of the range resulted in the loss of some grass species, riparian vegetation, and young aspen and willow trees. Restoration of riparian areas began in the early 1970s, and plans to reduce grazing were implemented in the 1980s and early 1990s. However, large wildfires in southeastern Oregon during the summer of 2012 burned much of the range's vegetation, damaging riparian ecosystems and killing hundreds of grazing cattle.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Animals in the Trout Creek Mountains are adapted to the environment of the High Desert. Pronghorn are common in the open, sagebrush @-@ covered
reference_text: basins, while mule deer live in the cottonwood and willow groves. There are also bighorn sheep, cougars, and bobcats in the high country. Jackrabbits and coyotes are prevalent throughout the range. Mustangs sometimes pass through the mountains as they roam the Great Basin. Some other mammals include the northern pocket gopher, mountain cottontail, and Belding's ground squirrel. North American beavers live in and along streams, as do Pacific tree frogs, western spadefoot toads, and garter snakes. Native bird species include the sage grouse, mountain chickadee, gray @-@ headed junco, black @-@ throated gray warbler, Virginia's warbler, MacGillivray's warbler, pine siskin, red crossbill, bushtit, hermit thrush, northern goshawk, and species of raven and eagle.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Several streams in the Trout Creek Mountains are home to trout, including the rare Lahontan cutthroat trout subspecies. These include Willow Creek, White
reference_text: horse Creek, Little Whitehorse Creek, Doolittle Creek, Fifteen Mile Creek, Indian Creek, Sage Canyon Creek, Line Canyon Creek, and some tributaries of McDermitt Creek. Lahontan cutthroat trout live in small, isolated populations that are often confined to individual streams, many of them in the Trout Creek Mountains. These populations have significant genetic differences due to their history of isolation. For most of the 20th century, the trout's numbers declined considerably. It was listed under federal law as an endangered species in 1970 and was reclassified as threatened in 1975. Reasons for the fish's decline included habitat degradation from cattle grazing, drought, overfishing, competition with other fish, and hybridization with introduced rainbow trout, which decreased the number of genetically pure Lahontan cutthroat trout. However, reductions in cattle grazing in riparian zones since the 1980s allowed fish habitat and populations to start to recover.

There are about 1,000 or more white-tailed cutthroat trout in the Tahoe Basin, according to Fish and Game. That's a lot of brook trout to keep tabs on, let alone all the waterfowl that come to roost in the stream or fly over as they forage for crayfish, mussels and other critters.

It's no surprise that people have been trying to figure out how to deal with the trout for a long time. One of the earliest attempts was an anti-poaching program that went into effect in the 1950s. The fish were hunted with hounds, but that proved to be a bad idea. Hounds are great at catching prey, but they have a hard time getting the job done when it comes to a predator on the prowl. In any case, the idea was scrapped for a more humane way to do things.

Over the years, efforts have been made to reintroduce the trout to the Tahoe Basin, but nothing has panned out as well as it could have. This is in

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Bureau of Land Management ( BLM ) administers most land in the Trout Creek Mountains, but there are also some private lands and some roads in the area
reference_text: . The private lands are mainly used for ranching along mountain streams, while the BLM lands include large grazing allotments for local ranchers'cattle. At least 100 mining claims in the mountains have been recorded since 1892, some of which were staked for gold exploration. Commercial mining has occurred in some areas, mostly near the McDermitt Caldera, where uranium and large amounts of mercury have been extracted. Mines in what was called the Opalite Mining District produced 270 @,@ 000 flasks of mercury — " the richest supply of mercury in the western hemisphere " — from cinnabar extracted from the caldera in the 20th century. The two leading mercury @-@ producing mines in North America were the Cordero and McDermitt mines on the edge of the caldera in Nevada. Together, they operated from 1933 to 1989. The McDermitt Mine, the last mercury mine in the United States, closed three years later, in 1992. However, mineral exploration has continued at the Cordero Mine in the 21st century, and waste containing mercury and arsenic was returned there from the community of McDermitt as part of a U.S. Environmental Protection Agency cleanup project.

Identification [ edit ]

Clustered bonnet caps are distinguished from other conifers by their spore print, which is reddish-brown in cross section rather than the white spore print of more closely related species. This can be a clue to the taxonomic status of the mushroom, as there are at least two genera of conifers that have white spore prints, such as Pinus sylvestris and Picea abies. A number of North American species are similar in appearance to the clustered bonnet cap, but do not have the red-brown spore print. In addition, mushroom identification is complicated by the fact that the mushroom grows on deciduous trees, and it is hard to tell at a glance whether a mushroom is associated with a shrub or a tree. For this reason, I have decided to stick with the more widely accepted name that is in common use on the interwebs, even though it is not my favorite.

There is a moment in The Imitation Game when Keira Knightley breaks down in tears. The reason is to do with Alan Turing, the codebreaker who revolutionised the field of cryptology after World War II. In an emotionally wrenching scene, Knightley's character, Cumberbatch's Turing, confesses to not being able to live with the knowledge that he was responsible for the death of millions of people. At the end of the film, we are left with the question: what is the world to do with a man who does not know what he did?

Turing's story is part of the background to Ian McKellen's magnificently understated performance as Arthur Kipps, the head of MI6 (the forerunner of the Bletchley Park codecrimes laboratory in Buckinghamshire). Kipps is in thrall to Lord Mountbatten, the King's cousin and one of the most powerful men in the world. This is a far cry from the macho swagger of Christopher Plummer's James Bond, but it is no less true to life. McKellen conveys the power of the man without patronising him, and in doing so elevates the role to a new level.

By car [ edit ]

There are toll plazas every 100 feet (30 m) on the New Jersey Turnpike that charge $1.50 to enter and exit. Paying the toll is optional, but it is a good idea to at least look at the placards before getting in your car. In addition, drivers are required to have a transponder on their motor vehicle that transmits their location to law enforcement if they are pulled over for a traffic violation. This does not apply to bicyclists, joggers, skaters, rollerbladers, strollers, or horseback riders.

Driving south on Route 29, you will see signs warning of speed traps and stop signs to slow down. Be on the lookout for police cruisers driving in the middle of the road, flashing their lights and sirens at you. Do not attempt to pass a police car or stop sign without signaling your intention to do so. The State Police have the right of way and will ticket you for impeding traffic.

If you are driving a four-wheel drive vehicle, make sure your tires are inflated to the proper pressure. Failure to do so can result in a $100 fine per tire. Check your tire pressure by pulling the air out of the tire and seeing if it

New Jersey Turnpike [ edit ]

A one-way system, the New Jersey Turnpike is divided into north and south sections. There are tolls on the north side ($1.50 per vehicle), and they are the same no matter which direction you are going. Tolls are charged at the end of each turnpike section, so be sure to pay your toll before getting off the turnpike. In addition to the tolls, a surcharge of $1.50 is charged for each round trip to and from the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Secaucus, New Jersey. This is an additional fee that must be paid in order to use the PABT. For more information, see the section on Transportation Alternatives below.

Pennsylvania Turnpike [ edit ]

The Pennsylvania Turnpike consists of two sections, the East and West Trunk. The East Trunk runs from I-95 in Cumberland County all the way to the Garden State Parkway in Bergen County. The West Trunk runs from I-95 in Ocean County all the way to the George Washington Bridge

It's hard to imagine a time when cars were the way of the road, but that's exactly what we have today. According to the National Park Service, there are more than 6.5 million cars on the road today, which is one of the highest rates of vehicular traffic in the country.

So what's the deal with so many cars zooming around San Diego like bumblebees? Why do we seem to have no end to traffic snarls every time the sun goes down? Let's take a look at the history of road construction in San Diego and figure out who's to blame.

1910-1940: Roads as Meters

For the first 40 years of the 20th century, the State of California was in the business of building roads as meters. At the time, this was a common practice in many parts of the world, most notably Great Britain. Roads were to be paid for by tolls, which were the equivalent of a gas tax back then. To do this, the state would set up a system of tollbooths along the road and, depending on the distance traveled, those who paid the toll would receive a meter reading on their license plate. That reading would be used to determine how much money was owed to the state.

Rhodesia gained independence in 1980, a year after the Berlin Wall fell. This was one of the most momentous events in the history of the world, and it seems to have passed unremarked by the news media. No one seems to have noticed that the Soviet Union broke off diplomatic relations with Zaire in August that year, and that on September 11, a bomb exploded in Belgrade, killing at least 100 people and injuring 1,000. Nor did anyone point out that, three or four months later, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire went on a bloodthirsty rampage, massacring as many as three million people, most of them Tutsis. In his diaries, Gorbachev wrote that he was "astonished" by the number of people killed in the East African civil war. (Gorbachev, Memoirs, p. 476-477) What was the world to think of a country that had done so much to destabilize the world, only to turn around and become a bulwark against it?

memory. One of the most well-known stories is the death of Cecil John Rhodes, the 19th Marquess of Salisbury, in 1883. According to the myth, Rhodes was ambushed by guerrillas on his way to a tea plantation in Transvaal, South Africa. After a gunfight, Rhodes was mortally wounded and his chauffeur, George Macpherson, took his body to Pretoria for burial.

Rhodes did not die in vain. By the time British colonials set up the Cape Colony in 1884, there were at least 1,000 Afrikaner (Ndebele) and Boer war veterans in the military, a far greater number than the British had expected. Some of these veterans fought their way to independence, such as Willem Groenewald, who defected to the British in 1885 to avoid conscription as a slave labourer. However, the war proved to be a turning point for the independence movement, ushering in a period of peace and prosperity that lasted until the Anglo-Boer War of 1899-1902.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Tikal ( / tiˈkäl / ) ( Tik ’ al in modern Mayan orthography ) is the ruins of an ancient city found
reference_text: in a rainforest in Guatemala. Ambrosio Tut, a gum @-@ sapper, reported the ruins to La Gaceta, a Guatemalan newspaper, which named the site Tikal. After the Berlin Academy of Sciences'magazine republished the report in 1853, archeologists and treasure hunters began visiting the forest. Today tourism to the site may help protect the rainforest. It is one of the largest archaeological sites and urban centers of the pre @-@ Columbian Maya civilization. Tikal dates back to the 3rd millennium BC, although archaeologists have known about it for thousands of years. Archaeological evidence suggests that Tikal was a cosmopolitan city with at least 10,000 inhabitants at its peak. This would make it the largest city in the New World by some margin. The city sprawled over an area of 1,890 km² (about the size of Rhode Island's Cranston-Auburn metropolitan area), and in some places was as large as the United States as a whole. As is the case with many pre-Columbian metropolises, trade was the lifeblood of the city, and there is evidence that people from all over the world flocked to Tikal to trade with each other. Some of the world's most famous artifacts were made in Tikal, including the Aztec pyramids, Olmec tombs, Teotihuacan palaces, and Inca altars.


Archaeobotanists excavated and catalogued the city's ruins in the 1950s and 1960s, and over the past half century or so a team of more than a dozen archaeologists has been working to unearth the secrets of Tikal. Their work has been aided

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Tikal was the capital of a conquest state that became one of the most powerful kingdoms of the ancient Maya. Though monumental architecture at the site dates back as
reference_text: far as the 4th century BC, Tikal reached its apogee during the Classic Period, c. 200 to 900 AD. During this time, the city dominated much of the Maya region politically, economically, and militarily, while interacting with areas throughout Mesoamerica such as the great metropolis of Teotihuacan in the distant Valley of Mexico. There is evidence that Tikal was conquered by Teotihuacan in the 4th century AD. Following the end of the Late Classic Period, no new major monuments were built at Tikal and there is evidence that elite palaces were burned. These events were coupled with a gradual population decline, culminating with the site ’ s abandonment by the end of the 10th century.

Tell us about your research.

Tikal was an important city-state in the Yucatan Peninsula, about 1,000 miles (1,600 kilometers) south of Mexico City. It was founded by Mayan conquerors who took over the city of Palenque in 10th century A.D. After several centuries of power, Tulampauqui, the last king of the city, ceded control to the Mexica—Mesoamerican nomads—in the 15th century. Over the next two centuries, the Mexica expanded their conquests, building pyramids, plazas, and canals to facilitate trade and military expeditions. These are the places we're focusing on in this project.

What's it like to excavate a site that's been under the radar for so long?

It's a different kind of excavation than you might expect. First of all, there's no scaffolding, no backhoes, no bulldozers. Everything is done by hand. This is the first time in the history of archaeology that we've been able

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The name Tikal may be derived from ti ak 'al in the Yucatec Maya language ; it is said to be a relatively modern name meaning
reference_text: " at the waterhole ". The name was apparently applied to one of the site's ancient reservoirs by hunters and travelers in the region. It has alternatively been interpreted as meaning " the place of the voices " in the Itza Maya language. Tikal, however, is not the ancient name for the site but rather the name adopted shortly after its discovery in the 1840s. Hieroglyphic inscriptions at the ruins refer to the ancient city as Yax Mutal or Yax Mutul, meaning " First Mutal ". Tikal may have come to have been called this because Dos Pilas also came to use the same emblem glyph ; the rulers of the city presumably wanted to distinguish themselves as the first city to bear the name. The kingdom as a whole was simply called Mutul, which is the reading of the " hair bundle " emblem glyph seen in the accompanying photo. Its precise meaning remains obscure.

The Mayan people of Mesoamerica developed a writing system based on pictographs, which became the basis of their civil and religious life. At one time or another, over a period of 1,000 years, the Toltec, Zapotec, Mixtec, Mestizos, Huastec, Totonac, Nahua, Arawak, Tepehuan, Chichimeca, Quiche, Nahuatl, Aztec, Copan, Oaxaca, Cakchiquel, Pima, and other peoples wrote their own languages, as well as those of the Olmecs, Tarascans, Incas, Aztecs, Mexica, etc. This has led to the question of whether there was a pre-Columbian connection between the Old and New World, or whether the development of writing was a result of intermarriages between the peoples of the two continents. In this article, we will look at the evidence for and against this theory. (For more information, see What Happened to the Maya? A Comparative Analysis of Archaeological and Ethnohistorical Evidence.)

Tikal is located in the Yucatan Peninsula, which is bordered by the Gulf of Mexico to the north, the Andes Mountains to the east, El Yunque National Park to the south, and the Tabasco Plateau to the west. The land has a temperate climate with subtropical and tropical climatic zones. The climate is moderated by the equatorial jet stream, which circulates over the Pacific Ocean and is the source of the monsoon rains that fertilize the plant life, as well as the trade winds that carry the sand dunes and sea breezes in the Gulf of Mexico. This location makes it a hot and arid region, but it is home to one of the world's largest oases, Punta Arenas, which is an important stop for migratory birds and waterfowl.

As an anthropologist, I spend a lot of time thinking about power. What does it mean to be powerful? How do we get our hands on it? And most importantly, how do we relinquish it? It's no surprise that my research has focused on this question, in part because power is at the core of so many of the conflicts that our world faces today. The Arab Spring, for example, was sparked by the uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt, among other countries, that took place in the wake of autocratic regimes toppling due to popular revolts. A decade later, there are no signs that the Middle East is on the cusp of a democratization—not yet, at least. This is the first in a series of articles that will seek to unpack the meaning of power in the post-Ottoman world.

Tikal was one of the most important pre-Columbian Mesoamerican cities, and its importance cannot be overstated. It was the capital of the Zapotec-Mesoamerican kingdom known as the Tiwanaku (pronounced tee-wah-koo and meaning "kingdom of the sun" in Quechua).[1] At its height, Dos Pilas spanned an area of 1,890 hectares (4,000 acres) and had a population of more than 100,000 people, of whom 80% were Toltec and 20% Aymara.[2] According to archeologist Hernán Cortés, this would have equated to one-third of the city's population.[3] By the time of the Spanish conquest, Dos Pilas had fallen into disrepair and was no longer of any use to the conquistadors, who did not bother to clean it up after their excursions to the New World. A few years later, in 1521, the Moors from Granada invaded the city, pillaging and desecrating the tombs of the Aztec emperors that had been interred there over the centuries. This was the beginning of the centuries-long Moorish occupation of the city, which lasted until the Spaniards recaptured it in 1540–1541.[4]

The beginning of the 10th Bak 'tun in 830 passed uncelebrated, and marks the beginning of a 60 @-@ year hiatus, probably resulting from the collapse of central control in the city. During this hiatus, satellite sites traditionally under Tikal's control began to erect their own monuments featuring local rulers and using the Mutal emblem glyph, with Tikal apparently lacking the authority or the power to crush these bids for independence. In 849, Jewel K 'awiil is mentioned on a stela at Seibal as visiting that city as the Divine Lord of Tikal but he is not recorded elsewhere and Tikal's once great power was little more than a memory. The sites of Ixlu and Jimbal had by now inherited the once exclusive Mutal emblem glyph.

Who and What Were the Classic Maya?

The Classic Maya were a Mesoamerican civilization that flourished from the first dynasties of the 3rd millennium B.C. to the fall of the Olmec civilization in the 10th century A.D. Most of the world's pre-Columbian civilizations, including the Aztecs, Incas, Zapotecs, Nahuas, Tiwanaku, Tikal, Quiché, Mixtecs, Moche, Totonac, Huastecs, Teotihuacán, Chichén Itzá, Toltecs, Cusco, Oaxaca, Xochimilco, Tenochtitlan, Palenque, Acapulco, Huehuetenango, Copán, Calakmul, San Bartolo, Yucatán, Campeche, Quintana Roo, Chiapas

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> In the latter half of the 9th century there was an attempt to revive royal power at the much diminished city of Tikal, as evidenced by a st
reference_text: ela erected in the Great Plaza by Jasaw Chan K 'awiil II in 869. This was the last monument erected at Tikal before the city finally fell into silence. The former satellites of Tikal, such as Jimbal and Uaxactun, did not last much longer, erecting their final monuments in 889. By the end of the 9th century the vast majority of Tikal's population had deserted the city, its royal palaces were occupied by squatters and simple thatched dwellings were being erected in the city's ceremonial plazas. The squatters blocked some doorways in the rooms they reoccupied in the monumental structures of the site and left rubbish that included a mixture of domestic refuse and non @-@ utilitarian items such as musical instruments. These inhabitants reused the earlier monuments for their own ritual activities far removed from those of the royal dynasty that had erected them. Some monuments were vandalized and some were moved to new locations. Before its final abandonment all respect for the old rulers had disappeared, with the tombs of the North Acropolis being explored for jade and the easier to find tombs being looted. After 950, Tikal was all but deserted, although a remnant population may have survived in perishable huts interspersed among the ruins. Even these final inhabitants abandoned the city in the 10th or 11th centuries and the rainforest claimed the ruins for the next thousand years. Some of Tikal's population may have migrated to the Peten Lakes region, which remained heavily populated in spite of a plunge in population levels in the first half of the 9th century.

Designed by Andres Sánchez in the 1970s, the digger is the brainchild of a Spaniard by the name of Vicente Arribas. According to Smithsonian.com, Arribas used parts of a tractors to create the contraption, which allowed him to dig a 10-meter (33-foot) trench at the site while maintaining a speed of up to 20 kilometers (12 miles) per hour. That's more than enough to do the job, and there's no need for a backhoe like you or I would need in order to get the job done.

Advertisement

Sánchez had his hands full with the digging, but what he lacked in speed he made up for in engineering acumen. For one thing, he figured out how to keep the machine from overheating, which is a problem that plagues excavators to this day. Another innovation was the construction of a heat exchanger, which converts heat from the engine into electricity for the power source. All in all, the result is a machine that not only shovels dirt, but makes it look effortless.

This article is about the World War II-era U.S. Air Force base. For the post-Apocalypse United States of America, see Camp McCarran.

Camp McCarran is a military base in the Mojave Wasteland in 2281. It is located south of Primm, on the border of Goodsprings and Freeside.

Contents show]

Background Edit

In the 20th century, the Army of the United States began to look for a place to base their war materiel.[1] They set up a base at Pahrump Dry Lake, an oasis in the arid wastelands of Nevada. After the Great War, the base was decommissioned and left to the ravages of time. Over the years, campers grew resentful of the lack of access to drinking water and trash, and attempted to take matters into their own hands. One such raider, Preston Garvey, became infatuated with the base and made it his life's work to clean up the mess left by the rest of the campers. His work proved fruitless, however, and Garvey went on to commit suicide by slitting his jugular with a shiv while under the influence of hallucinogenic bergamot-laced tequila.[2]

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The North Acropolis, together with the Great Plaza immediately to the south, is one of the most studied architectural groups in the Maya area ; the Tikal
reference_text: Project excavated a massive trench across the complex, thoroughly investigating its construction history. It is a complex group with construction beginning in the Preclassic Period, around 350 BC. It developed into a funerary complex for the ruling dynasty of the Classic Period, with each additional royal burial adding new temples on top of the older structures. After AD 400 a row of tall pyramids was added to the earlier Northern Platform, which measured 100 by 80 metres ( 330 by 260 ft ), gradually hiding it from view. Eight temple pyramids were built in the 6th century AD, each of them had an elaborate roofcomb and a stairway flanked by masks of the gods. By the 9th century AD, 43 stelae and 30 altars had been erected in the North Acropolis ; 18 of these monuments were carved with hieroglyphic texts and royal portraits. The North Acropolis continued to receive burials into the Postclassic Period.

Architecture as a Way of Life

There is no doubt that the pyramids were designed to serve as tombs for the pharaohs, as we know them today. This is no small matter, in an area where death was a constant companion from the Mesoamerican point of view. It is hard to imagine life without funerary monuments, and many of the world's pre-Columbian cultures seem to have done the same. Archaeologists have found mummified burials in the Valley of Mexico, dating back to 3,000 years ago, and at Palenque, a Mayan city that thrived as long as A.D. 800. Even so, the construction of pyramid-shaped cemeteries did not become common until the 18th century, when Spain colonized the Isthmus of Tehuantepec and began excavating the city of Tenochtitlan. By the time Spaniards arrived, the Aztecs had already laid to rest tens of thousands of their compatriots in what is now the Yucatan Peninsula.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Mundo Perdido is to the west of the Plaza of the Seven Temples. It is the largest ceremonial complex dating from the Preclassic period
reference_text: at Tikal. The complex was organized as a large E @-@ Group consisting of a pyramid aligned with a platform to the east that supported three temples. The Mundo Perdido complex was rebuilt many times over the course of its history. By AD 250 – 300 its architectural style was influenced by the great metropolis of Teotihuacan in the Valley of Mexico, including the use of the talud @-@ tablero form. During the Early Classic period ( c. 250 – 600 ) the Mundo Perdido became one of the twin foci of the city, the other being the North Acropolis. From AD 250 to 378 it may have served as the royal necropolis. The Mundo Perdido complex was given its name by the archaeologists of the University of Pennsylvania ; it is centered upon the Lost World Pyramid and a small platform to the west of it.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Temple I ( also known as the Temple of Ah Cacao or Temple of the Great Jaguar ) is a funerary pyramid dedicated to Jasaw Chan K
reference_text: 'awil, who was entombed in the structure in AD 734, the pyramid was completed around 740 – 750. The temple rises 47 metres ( 154 ft ) high. The massive roofcomb that topped the temple was originally decorated with a giant sculpture of the enthroned king, although little of this decoration survives. The tomb of the king was discovered by Aubrey Trik of the University of Pennsylvania in 1962. Among items recovered from the Late Classic tomb were a large collection of inscribed human and animal bone tubes and strips with sophisticated scenes depicting deities and people, finely carved and rubbed with vermilion, as well as jade and shell ornaments and ceramic vessels filled with offerings of food and drink. The shrine at the summit of the pyramid has three chambers, each behind the next, with the doorways spanned by wooden lintels fashioned from multiple beams. The outermost lintel is plain but the two inner lintels were carved, some of the beams were removed in the 19th century and their location is unknown, while others were taken to museums in Europe.

This number was the highest of any temple in the city up to that time. As time went on, the temple shrank in size, and was no longer the largest or most ornate of the city's mausoleums. Temple I continued to be used as a burial site until the 1980s, when it was declared a Unesco World Heritage Site.


TEMPLE I'S DESIGN FEATURES INCLUDE: An obelisk-shaped stone pedestal on which is enshrined a carving of a stylized phoenix, its wings spread to symbolize the flight of the sun. There is also a representation of the Lotus Sutra in the center of the temple. Inside the temple, visitors will find a number of niches that allow worshippers to rest their heads on the sarcophagus of a deceased devotee. Each nook and cranny is filled with incense, chrysanthemums, lotus petals, and, of course, jade.

reference_text: Acropolis. It started life in the Early Classic as a wide basal platform decorated with large stucco masks that flanked the stairway. Later in the Early Classic a new superstructure was added, with its own masks and decorated panels. During the Hiatus a third stage was built over the earlier constructions, the stairway was demolished and another royal burial, of an unidentified ruler, was set into the structure ( Burial 23 ). While the new pyramid was being built another high ranking tomb ( Burial 24 ) was inserted into the rubble core of the building. The pyramid was then completed, standing 33 metres ( 108 ft ) tall. The final version of Temple 33 was completely dismantled by archaeologists in 1965 in order to arrive at the earlier stages of construction.

edit] History

Aerial view of Temple 33 (courtesy of Google Earth)

The construction of Temple 33 began in the 2nd century bce, and according to Herodotus of Halicarnassus, King Antiochus IV Epiphanes "consecrated an obelisk of enormous size to the memory of his father Seleucus Nicator, and in the year four hundred and sixty-eighth decreed that it should be a mausoleum for his son Antiochus the Great."[1] At the time of the Great Revolt of the Hasmonean and Ptolemaic dynasties in 597 bce, the city of Palmyra was under the control of the Nabateans, who attempted to re-capture the city by besieging it with siege engines and battering rams. This did not go well, and the city was retaken by the Persians in 605 bce. As a result of this victory, the Roman Emperor Vespasian was sent to Palmyra to mediate a peace between the two feuding factions. His mission was a resounding success, and he established a base of operations in the city, which he named Caesarea Maritima

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Structure 5D @-@ 43 is an unusual radial temple in the East Plaza, built over a pre @-@ existing twin pyramid complex. It is
reference_text: built into the end of the East Plaza Ballcourt and possessed four entry doorways and three stairways, the fourth ( south ) side was too close to the Central Acropolis for a stairway on that side. The building has a talud @-@ tablero platform profile, modified from the original style found at Teotihuacan. In fact, it has been suggested that the style of the building has closer affinities with El Tajin and Xochicalco than with Teotihuacan itself. The vertical tablero panels are set between sloping talud panels and are decorated with paired disc symbols. Large flower symbols are set into the sloping talud panels, related to the Venus and star symbols used at Teotihuacan. The roof of the structure was decorated with friezes although only fragments now remain, showing a monstrous face, perhaps that of a jaguar, with another head emerging from the mouth. The second head possesses a bifurcated tongue but is probably not that of a snake. The temple, and its associated ballcourt, probably date to the reign of Nuun Ujol Chaak or that of his son Jasaw Chan K 'awiil I, in the later part of the 7th century.

reference_text: all directions, and it is very close to central Colorado's Collegiate Peaks. The neighboring Mount Massive, to the north, is the second @-@ highest peak in the Rocky Mountains and the third @-@ highest in the contiguous United States, and La Plata Peak, to the south, is the fifth @-@ highest in the Rockies. The community of Twin Lakes lies at the base of Mount Elbert, Denver is about 130 miles ( 209 km ) to the east, Vail is 50 miles ( 80 km ) to the north, and Aspen is 40 miles ( 64 km ) to the west. Leadville, about 16 miles ( 26 km ) to the northeast, is the nearest large town. Elbert's parent peak is Mount Whitney in California. Including Alaska and Hawaii, Mount Elbert is the fourteenth @-@ highest mountain in the United States.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Mount Elbert is part of the Sawatch Range, an uplift of the Laramide Orogeny which separated from the Mosquito Range to the
reference_text: east around 28 million years ago. The tops of this range were heavily glaciated, leaving behind characteristic summit features and other such clues. For example, the base of Elbert on the eastern side exhibits large igneous and metamorphic rocks deposited when the glaciers receded, which lie on a lateral moraine. Further up the eastern side there is a large cirque with a small tarn. There are also lakes to both the north and south, Turquoise and Twin Lakes respectively ; the Twin Lakes are a result of the natural dam of end moraines, and Turquoise Lake was created by the manmade Sugar Loaf Dam.

Geography Edit

Mount Elbert is a volcanic caldera surrounded by a ring of ridges and canyons. The top of the caldera is at 2,500 feet (800 m) above sea level, and slopes down to the lake-basin below. There are no waterfalls, rapids, or ice crevasses to be found on the mountain. Inhabitants are nomadic wanderers whose way of life is based on self-sufficiency and adaptability. As such, they have little need for foodstuffs, except what they scavenge from the wild for sustenance. This, combined with the cold, low humidity, and arid climate, results in a population of over one million per square mile (500 km2 or 0.6 sq mi). Most of the population subsists on deer, elk, moose, bison, pronghorn antelope, caribou, beaver, muskrat, otter, mink, porcupine, marten, badger, hare, raccoon, skunk, opossum, wolverine, lynx, bobcat, coyote, mountain lion, cougar, grizzly bear, black bear, polar bear, sea otter, walrus, narwhal, beluga whale, humpback whale, harbor porpo

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Originally measured as 14 @,@ 433 feet ( 4 @,@ 399 m ) in height, Mount Elbert's elevation was later adjusted to 14
reference_text: @,@ 440 feet ( 4 @,@ 400 m ) following a re @-@ evaluation of mapped elevations, which sparked protests. The actual change was made in 1988 as a result of the North American Vertical Datum of 1988 ; it seems the original measurement resulted from the Sea Level Datum of 1929. A matter of some contention arose after the Great Depression over the heights of Elbert and its neighbor, Mount Massive, which differ in elevation by only 12 feet ( 3 @.@ 7 m ). This led to an ongoing dispute that came to a head with the Mount Massive supporters building large piles of stones on the summit to boost its height, only to have the Mount Elbert proponents demolish them. The effort was ultimately unsuccessful and Mount Elbert has remained the highest peak in Colorado. The first motorized ascent of Elbert occurred in 1949, when a Jeep was driven to the summit, apparently to judge suitability for skiing development.

Elevation and topography [ edit ]

As you drive through the foothills of the Cascades, it is easy to get lost in the forest for a few minutes. This is no fault of the road, but an intentional design that minimizes wind resistance and helps maintain a low center of gravity. At the same time, the trees are close together, making it difficult to see the contours of the mountain and what lies beneath. There are no trail junctions, so be sure to bring a map and compass. In the winter, snowdrifts up to 1/2 mile (1.6 km) high are common due to the presence of glacial ice. These have to be traversed by skiers/snowboarders, and should be avoided at all costs. Also, bear canisters are a no-no on this mountain, as they pose a fire hazard.

Also noted are Carex atrata var. pullata, Salix desertorum, Platanthera hyperborea, Thalictrum fendleri, Aquilegia canadensis, Chenopodium album, Gentiana detonsa var. hallii, and Bigelovia parryi. Below treeline the mountain is heavily forested, with the lower slopes covered with a mixture of lodgepole pine, spruce, aspen and fir.

Photo by the author with permission. Click on the photo for a larger version.

Here are some photos of the flower in bloom that I took over the course of 10 or so minutes. As you can see, not only are the flowers a few feet (meters) away from the tree trunks, but they are surrounded by a ring of blossoms at the base of the tree. This is a sign of pollination, which occurs when pollen from one flower fertilizes the pollen of another flower. In this case, the flower is Phacelia sericea, a type of evergreen shrub native to the Himalayas. It is named for the star-shaped petals that look like a bird's beak. Origins Edit

The Church of Scientology was founded in Los Angeles, California, by science fiction writer L. Ron Hubbard in 1954. At the time, Hubbard was a penniless writer working as a janitor at a movie theater. His interest in Scientology was sparked by a reading of Dianetics, a self-help book written by Robert Lifton, a psychoanalyst who helped develop the concept of lobotomies by removing people's ability to feel pain. [1]

Hollywood celebrities and business tycoons flocked to the church, and by the 1960s, Scientology had become a multimillion-dollar business. Its headquarters were located in Hemet, California, an unincorporated community in the San Fernando Valley (see Valley of the Sikhs). This area was home to over 1,000 Scientologists, many of whom were well-heeled and middle-class Californians. The church began to expand in the United States and other countries, opening "Ideal Orgs" in New York City, San Francisco, and Washington, D.C. Technology & Combat Characteristics Edit

The Asahi-class destroyers were designed to take on the U.S. Navy's Type 0-9 Shokaku-class carriers and Zuikaku-class destroyers. In this role, they excelled, winning the Battle of Midway in 1942 and the Battle of Leyte Gulf in 1944. This proved to be the high point of the design, as it was one of the few ships to survive the end of World War II unscathed. (LOGH: 'The Uninvited Dilemma', 'Solitary Pursuit')

Armament Edit

Main Turrets Edit

Twin.50 caliber machine guns on the foresides of the superstructure. These were capable of firing anti-aircraft shells up to 1500 meters per second, and their armor plating was sufficient to repel high-explosive shells. A torpedo launcher was mounted on the starboard side of the superstructure. There were at least two launch tubes for torpedoes, and each ship carried an A-Division of torpedo escorts. (LOGH: 'Deserter in Distress')

The Death Star was a battlestation in the Galactic Empire's armada. It was the largest and most powerful Star Destroyer in the Imperial fleet, rivaling the Executor-class Star Dreadnought in size and power. At one point, the Death Star was used to destroy the Mon Calamari Cruiser Tantive IV by ramming it with its turbolaser emplacements, resulting in the destruction of the bridge crew and the ship's starfighter escorts. This was the first time Darth Vader was present in the Battle of Yavin.[1]

The Type XVII was armed with a total of 1,764.303 inch (7.62 mm) Browning machine guns, along with an additional 9.2 x 57 mm (≈ 0.50 in) M1919A4 machine guns. In addition, there were two 7.62 x 51 mm (≈ 0.30 in) anti-aircraft machine guns for self-defence. It was one of the most powerful cruisers in the world at the time of its construction, and could lay down a fire rate of one salvo every two seconds without overheating. This was due to the design of the superstructure, which was divided into sections rather than a monolithic 'bulletproof' structure. As a result, heat was dissipated by convection, rather than radiating from the ship like on a battleship. To this end, the boilers were located close to the centre of the ship, and air was vented from the bow in order to provide cooling. These features proved to be essential in the frigid waters of the North Atlantic, where icebergs were a common occurence.

Harvey armour was a type of armour used by the British to protect against shell fire during the Napoleonic Wars. It consisted of a plate of high-velocity steel (reinforced with rivets) encased in a watertight shell. The thickness of the armour was such that water could not seep through without rupturing the armour, resulting in a fire hazard. As far as we know, there were no records of it being used in WWI. Its use was discontinued in the 1920s due to cost and obsolescence. At the time of the Warring States Period (794-1127 A.D.) and the Edo Period (1185-1333 A.D.), Japanese armour was similar to that of the Mongols, in that it consisted of two or three layers of hard-plastic armour welded together. This had the advantage of being impervious to shrapnel, but was heavy and unwieldy, necessitating the use of lances rather than javelins. In the Tokugawa Period (1333-1603 A.D.), the Japanese started to experiment with more modern armour, such as wrought iron breastplates, but did not go as far as the British and were content with the protection provided by Harvey armour. After the Meiji Restoration (1868-1912 A.D.),

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Asahi, meaning " rising sun ", a poetic name for Japan from a stanza of waka poetry, was laid down on 1 August 1898 in
reference_text: Clydebank, Scotland, by the Clydebank Engineering & Shipbuilding Co. and completed by John Brown & Company, which purchased the firm before Asahi was completed. She was launched on 13 March 1899 and completed on 31 July 1900. Her completion was delayed by about three months when her bottom plating required repairs after running aground off Southsea following sea trials. The ship departed England, after repairs in Portsmouth, on the day of her completion, and arrived at Yokosuka, Japan, on 23 October 1900. Asahi became flagship of the Standing Fleet on 22 May 1901 and was assigned to the 1st Battleship Division of the 1st Fleet when the Combined Fleet was re @-@ formed on 28 December 1903.

Asahi Shimbun (Tokyo) reported that the name was chosen to symbolize the growth of the country, and it was pronounced "sa-HAH-kee", an abbreviation of the kanji 和春日本 (Hasegawa Seishinsen) meaning "spring and summer". According to the dictionary A Guide to Nihongo-Etymology, the name has been in use since the 18th century, and there are at least two well-known spellings: Asahi and Asahi-shi. Both pronunciations are based on the katakana syllabary as well as the romanization of the name. This is in contrast to the use of the name Shingo, which is said to be derived from the Latin "sonus", meaning "sun". In any case, the name became the most popular name for Japanese surnames in the 20th century. [1]

Somewhat coincidentally, the name Asahi was given to the capital city of Japan by the Emperor Meiji (1868-1912) in his New Year's address to the people of Japan. He was making a point of saying that the government had no business taking care of the day-to-day affairs of the people,

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> At the start of the Russo @-@ Japanese War, Asahi, commanded by Captain Hikohachi Yamada, was assigned to the 1st Division
reference_text: of the 1st Fleet. She participated in the Battle of Port Arthur on 9 February 1904, when Vice Admiral Tōgō Heihachirō led the 1st Fleet in an attack on the Russian ships of the Pacific Squadron anchored just outside Port Arthur. Tōgō had expected the surprise night attack by his destroyers to be much more successful than it was, anticipating that the Russians would be badly disorganized and weakened, but they had recovered from their surprise and were ready for his attack. The Japanese ships were spotted by the protected cruiser Boyarin, which was patrolling offshore and alerted the Russian defences. Tōgō chose to attack the Russian coastal defences with his main armament and engage the ships with his secondary guns. Splitting his fire proved to be a poor decision as the Japanese eight @-@ inch ( 203 mm ) and six @-@ inch guns inflicted little damage on the Russian ships, which concentrated all their fire on the Japanese ships with some effect. Although many ships on both sides were hit, Russian casualties numbered only 17, while the Japanese suffered 60 killed and wounded before Tōgō disengaged. Asahi was not hit during the engagement.

History Edit

Early in the War of 1812, the U.S. Navy began construction of what would become the world's first battleship, the USS Constitution. In 1813, the United States entered the War of 1812 to protect its trade routes from British encroachment. This resulted in the opening of the Suez Canal, which brought a flood of gold to the United States. As a result, the economy boomed, and President James Madison became the first president to win re-election in 1824. During the war, the war had no discernible effect on the state of the shipbuilding industry in the United States, except for the loss of one shipyard at Jamestown, Virginia. (PROSE: Engines of War)

A year later, an attempt to take San Francisco by the renegade Time Lords from the Celestial Toypilots went pear-shaped. The TARDIS materialised in the Golden Gate Bridge, where it came under attack by Daleks piloted by Davros. (PROSE: Lungbarrow)

History Edit

Asahi was one of the most well-known cruisers of the Imperial Japanese Navy (IJN), due to her role in the Battle of Midway in World War II. At the time of the IJN's surrender, she was decommissioned and assigned to the newly formed U.S. Navy (USN), along with a number of other destroyers, frigates, and corvettes. (DS9: "The Search, Part I", "The Search, Part II")

A photo of Asahi in Singapore on 13 March 1942. This photo was taken by Rop Gong-shun, who was a cameraman for NHK (Japan Broadcasting Corporation). (courtesy of Chris Kennedy)

According to Chris Kennedy, "Rop Gong-shun was a cameraman for NHK (Japan Broadcasting Corporation) in the 1940s and his job was to film crew members as they worked on the battleships Nagato and Hashirajima. One day he happened to be photographing the aircraft carrier Ise-Shima and took a picture of what I believe to be the first-ever use of Kodak Ektar film in a war zone."

Kennedy added, "At the time, there was no word of Japan's entry into the war, just World War II as we know it today. It was a time of war, and the camera was the weapon of choice for newsgathering, not the camera that captures stills on film. Asahi was an island-based camera company, and they had a lot of work to do in order to stay afloat during the war. Their repair and refit work on the Naka was part of that work." prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The 1888 – 89 New Zealand Native football team was a New Zealand rugby union team that toured Britain, Ireland, Australia and New Zealand in 1888 and 1889.
reference_text: It mostly comprised players of Māori ancestry, and also included some Pākehā ( white New Zealanders ). A wholly private endeavour, the tour was not under the auspices of any official rugby authority ; it was organised by New Zealand international player Joseph Warbrick, promoted by civil servant Thomas Eyton, and managed by James Scott, a publican. The Natives were the first New Zealand team to perform a haka, and also the first to wear all black. They played 107 rugby matches during the tour, as well as a small number of Victorian Rules football and association football matches in Australia. Having made a significant impact on the development of New Zealand rugby, the Natives were inducted into the International Rugby Board Hall of Fame in 2008.

The team finished 4th in the Pacific Coast Football League (PCFL) and lost to the Los Angeles Argos in the Quarter-Finals. This was the first time in the history of the PCFL that a team had come within a point of winning the championship.
