The International Rugby Board (IRB) on Tuesday (22 February) made the announcement after months of wrangling with the WRU, which is locked in a stand-off over the length of the Lions tour.

The WRU has called for the tour to be curtailed to two years, in order to save money and avoid "potentially destabilising" the union's long-term financial position.

As a result, the IRB has agreed to change the tournament's fixture list to one that "delivers the best balance between revenue and fixture" and minimises the impact on the teams that take part.

There will be no change to the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) World Cup Qualifiers, which kick off on Saturday, 18 March.

This is significant because it means England will not be drawn against the Wallabies in Pool A at Lord's until the quarter-finals, rather than the first or second match of the tournament.

The changes will be finalised in due course and it is unclear when they will be implemented.

Many of the Natives did not survive the winter, and those who did were in poor health when they arrived in Melbourne in the spring. As far as I can make out, no record of the Wandjina survives to this day.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Despite his reputation as an artist and seal @-@ carver, Hu was primarily a publisher. His publishing house, the Ten Bamboo Studio, produced
reference_text: reference works on calligraphy, poetry and art ; medical textbooks ; books on etymology and phonetics ; and copies of as well as commentaries on the Confucian Classics. Unlike other publishers in the area, the Ten Bamboo Studio did not publish works of narrative fiction such as plays or novels. This bias towards academia was likely a consequence of the studio's location : the mountain on which Hu took up residence was just to the north of the Nanjing Guozijian ( National Academy ), which provided a captive market for academic texts. Between 1627 and 1644, the Ten Bamboo Studio produced over twenty printed books of this kind, aimed at a wealthy, literary audience. The studio's earliest publications were medical textbooks, the first of which, Tested Prescriptions for Myriad Illnesses ( Wanbing Yanfang, 萬病驗方 ) was published in 1631 and proved popular enough to be reissued ten years later. Hu's brother Zhengxin was a medical practitioner and appears to have been the author of these books.

In the 1930s, Hu moved to Hong Kong, where he became a friend of John Cheung, the poet and playwright. Cheung helped Hu set up a publishing house, the Ten Bamboo Studio, in the mid-1930s. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Ming dynasty had seen considerable advancement in the process of colour printing in China. At his studio, Hu Zhengyan experimented with various forms of woodblock printing
reference_text: , creating processes for producing multi @-@ coloured prints and embossed printed designs. As a result, he was able to produce some of China's first printed publications in colour, using a block printing technique known as " assorted block printing " ( douban yinshua, 饾板印刷 ). This system made use of multiple blocks, each carved with a different part of the final image and each bearing a different colour. It was a lengthy, painstaking process, requiring thirty to fifty engraved printing blocks and up to seventy inkings and impressions to create a single image. Hu also employed a related form of multiple @-@ block printing called " set @-@ block printing " ( taoban yinshua, 套板印刷 ), which had existed since the Yuan period some 200 years earlier but had only recently come into fashion again. He refined these block printing techniques by developing a process for wiping some of the ink off the blocks before printing ; this enabled him to achieve gradation and modulation of shades which were not previously possible.

The Book of Poetry was an instant success, and Hu Zhengyan went on to print hundreds of copies of the book every year for the next fifty years. This success was due in no small part to the fact that there was no market for poetry in the pre-literate society of the Ming dynasty. By the time of the book's publication, China was a multi-lingual society, in which every part of the country had its own language, and poetry was no exception. It was common for people to make pilgrimages to their hometowns to pay obeisance to their ancestors, and these visits took place in their native tongue. As a result, the poetic traditions of the home region were passed down from generation to generation, and poets, in turn, became familiar with the folktales and fables that served as the basis for their storytelling. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Hu's most notable work is the Ten Bamboo Studio Manual of Painting and Calligraphy ( Shizhuzhai Shuhuapu,
reference_text: 十竹齋書畫譜 ), an anthology of around 320 prints by around thirty different artists ( including Hu himself ), published in 1633. It consists of eight sections, covering calligraphy, bamboo, flowers, rocks, birds and animals, plums, orchids and fruit. Some of these sections had been released previously as single volumes. As well as a collection of artworks, it was also intended as an artistic primer, with instructions on correct brush position and technique and several pictures designed for beginners to copy. Although these instructions only appear in the sections on orchids and bamboo, the book still remains the first example of a categorical and analytical approach to Chinese painting. In this book, Hu used his multiple @-@ block printing methods to obtain gradations of colour in the images, rather than obvious outlines or overlaps. The manual is bound in the " butterfly binding " ( hudie zhuang, 蝴蝶裝 ) style, whereby whole @-@ folio illustrations are folded so that each occupies a double @-@ page spread. This binding style allows the reader to lay the book flat in order to look at a particular image. Cambridge University Library released a complete digital scan of the manual, including all writings and illustrations in August, 2015. Said Charles Aylmer, Head of the Cambridge University Chinese Department, " The binding is so fragile, and the manual so delicate, that until it was digitized, we have never been able to let anyone look through it or study it – despite its undoubted importance to scholars. I was fortunate to have a copy of this on my bookshelf for a long time. It is a must-have for anyone interested in Hu's art. There are hundreds of illustrations to be found in the book, but my favorite is the one showing Hu's brushstrokes in three-dimensions. They are the closest we will ever get to seeing the work of a master at work.


Huj's teaching style is based on what he calls "solitary practice," which means no matter what you are doing, you have to stay in the present moment. This does not mean he eschews practice, but it does mean that practice is a byproduct of one's life, not the other way around. Hu has an easy way of putting it: "Practice is nothing but moving your body from one place to another at the speed of a hummingbird." As long as you are making progress, that is all that matters.

Hu's interest in typography was piqued by the success of Lin Yutang's work in the 1920s and 1930s, and he set about making his own typefaces. In 1930, he was commissioned by the Guangzhou Textile Manufacturers' Association to produce a hand-illustrated brochure for the production of textiles. This resulted in the design of the Guilin-based Sans Serif and Sans Oblique series, which were the first commercially successful sans serifs in China. Later, Hu worked on the introduction of China's first monospaced typewriter, the Tianshan Shoujiazhuang, as well as the Huineng Type Foundry, which began production in the mid-1930s.


Hudson & Bohannon's catalog of Hu's work can be found in the Library of Congress Rare Book and Special Collections Division Manuscript Division. More information about Hu's work can be found in A Concise History of Chinese Typography by J.A. Breslau (Princeton University Press, 1995). prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Raid on Manila of January 1798 was a Royal Navy false flag military operation during the French Revolutionary Wars intended to scout the strength of the defences of Manila
reference_text: , capital of the Spanish Philippines, capture a Manila galleon and assess the condition of the Spanish Navy squadron maintained in the port. Spain had transformed from an ally of Great Britain in the War of the First Coalition into an enemy in 1796. Thus the presence of a powerful Spanish squadron at Manila posed a threat to the China Fleet, an annual convoy of East Indiaman merchant ships from Macau in Qing Dynasty China to Britain, which was of vital economic importance to Britain. So severe was this threat that a major invasion of the Spanish Philippines had been planned from British India during 1797, but had been called off following the Treaty of Campo Formio in Europe and the possibility of a major war in India between the British East India Company and the Kingdom of Mysore.

Background Edit

The plot revolves around King Philip II of Spain, who at the time was in the process of consolidating his power in the New World. On January 1798, Spanish admiral Ismael Pérez de Lozada set sail from Cadiz en route to Manila, under the pretence of a search for gold. This was in an attempt to gain a toehold in the South China Sea, which was of great strategic importance to Spain. Upon arriving in Manila, Pérez de Lozada made his way to the governor's palace, where he was accosted by a group of discontented Spaniards demanding his ouster. Realising that the situation was untenable, Pérez de Lozada attempted to flee the city by means of a cannonball that was fired at him from the top of the Pantheon. The cannonball ricocheted off the Pantheon and struck an unguarded window, causing a fire that burned for several days. After extinguishing the fire, Pérez de Lozada took refuge in the city's military barracks, where he was taken prisoner by the military and held incommunicado from the general population.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> In 1796, after three years of the French Revolutionary Wars, Spain and the French Republic signed the Treaty of San Ildefonso. The secret terms
reference_text: of this treaty required Spain to renounce its alliance with Great Britain and subsequently to declare war on its former ally. In the East Indies this shift of political allegiance meant that the dominant British forces in the region were faced with the threat of attack from the Spanish Philippines to the east. Britain dominated the East Indies in 1796, controlling the trade routes through the Indian Ocean from the ports of Bombay, Madras and Calcutta. Dutch Ceylon, the Dutch Cape Colony and parts of the Dutch East Indies had been captured in 1795, and the French presence in the region had been confined to Île de France and a few subsidiary islands in the Western Indian Ocean.

According to the treaty, the Spaniards ceded Algiers to France without indemnity, on the condition that France would be reimbursed for the cost of fortifications and war reparations. This stipulation was a precondition for Spain's reoccupation of Algiers as a protectorate. At the same time, Spain relinquished its claim to the Suez Canal and a part of the Algerian Diaspora. In other words, the Spanish did not renounce any of their conquests, but they made it clear that they were no longer going to get anything in return for them.


What's the deal with the title "Territorial Clauses Concerning the Occupation of Algiers"? Why did the French have to sign a treaty of this nature? And more importantly, how did this treaty come to be the basis for the Franco-Spanish border that we see today? Read on to find out. China Trunk convoys had a name that gave them their name, but there were many other names for the convoy as well. For example, the Shandong Trunk was an even larger convoy consisting of over 1,000 wagons loaded with silks, jade, pearls, etc. (Wikipedia).

Canton, Hong Kong's port, was one of the most important ports in the world at the time. This is because Canton was the home of the Silk Road, a trade route that spanned the Eurasian continent from China to the Mediterranean Sea. Chinese navigators used the Silk Road to trade with all of the civilizations along the way. These voyages were long and arduous, and required the crew to be on the move for months at a time. It was no wonder that the Chinese felt a kinship with the Mongols, who were similar in many ways to the Chinese.

Mongols first set foot on the shores of China in the 6th century, but their history goes back much further. The nomadic Khwarezmian tribes lived in the steppes of what is now Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan. Over the centuries,

One of the most well-known stories of the trade voyages of the seventeenth century is the so-called "Treasure Island" incident. There is no evidence that the island was ever known as Treasure Island, but it was an important stopping point for merchant ships en route to Canton, Hong Kong, and other far-flung outposts of the Far East. On May 3, 1797, a Royal Navy frigate, HMS Endeavour, sighted the island and radioed the Admiralty to report that it was laden with gold ingots as well as "various valuables of every description." Within a few days, the admiral in charge of the Indian Ocean trade, Rear Admiral Francis Paget, made a secret rendezvous with his counterpart in Hong Kong, Rear Admiral Ching Kwan-yin, and agreed to set sail that May

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> With his convoy safely at anchor in Macau and the China Fleet several weeks from sailing, Cooke decided to reconnoitre Manila and make observations on the
reference_text: port and the Spanish squadron based there. As an added motivation, rumours in Macau suggested that the annual Manila galleon was due to arrive. This ship brought up to two million Spanish silver dollars from Acapulco across the Pacific Ocean stopping at Guam on its way to Manila. Depositing its dollars in the Philippines, the ship then loaded trade goods from the East Indies for the return journey to New Spain. This round trip was essential to the maintenance of the Spanish Empire in the East Indies, which operated at an enormous financial loss only mitigated by the substantial subsidy from New Spain. Spanish dollars were the accepted currency across most of the East Indies, and disruption of this financial system could have profound effects on regional trade ; but British sailors had nevertheless been attacking the Manila galleons since Thomas Cavendish in 1587.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Cooke led his small squadron past Corregidor on 15 January and turned south. Four days later in a storm one of the gunboats broke its tow
reference_text: line and was never seen again, lost with its twelve crew. The frigates subsequently scouted Mindanao before reaching Zamboanga on 22 January. There Cooke raised Spanish colours in an attempt to deceive the authorities into supplying food and water to his squadron but Sybille grounded on a sandbank at the entrance to the port which raised the suspicions of a guardboat sent by the governor of Zamboanga, Raymundo Español. The captain of the Spanish boat asked the British ships the names of their captains, and on receiving no answer but a volley of rifle fire, he put the town on alert. With the defenders forewarned, Cooke abandoned his ruse and after refloating Sybille the following morning, ordered a bombardment of the fort protecting the harbour. This had little effect, though later the Spanish recovered at least 450 cannonballs from different calibers, and Malcolm then attempted an amphibious landing in order to storm the landward side of the fort. The boats came under heavy fire, one smashed by a cannonball, killing two and wounding four. Another boat grounded on a sandbar and became stuck ; so with his force in disarray, as 250 villagers armed with lances ambushed and drove the British from the beach, Malcolm called off the operation. After exchanging shot for an hour both frigates cut their anchor cables and retreated out of range, with two dead and one wounded on Sybille and eight wounded on Fox, in addition to those lost in the boats. The defenders lost a single man killed and 4 wounded.

Cooke's "Dangerous Liaison" was part of a wave of anti-Spanish propaganda that swept the United States in the 1820s and 1830s. At the time, the war was in its death throes, and there was a lot of pent-up resentment against the Spanish for everything from enslaving the Filipinos to torturing and slaughtering Native Americans. By this time, American sympathies were split between North and South, and it was common for Americans to side with the South in matters of war. This, combined with the rise of nativist fervor in the mid-1830s, resulted in an outpouring of anti-Spanish sentiment, both in the country and beyond. One of the most virulent pamphlets was published in New York by Benjamin Franklin Bache, a self-styled "Philosopher of the Colonies." The pamphlet, An Essay on the Misery of Spain, argued that Spain was to blame for the Philippines' poor harvests, disease, and depopulation. Bache's vitriol was directed at King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella, who had taken the Philippines from Spain in the 17th century. To add insult to injury, Bache claimed that the Spanish

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The 1798 China Fleet sailed without further incident. During the ensuing year Resistance was destroyed by an accidental explosion in July in the Bangka Strait, and the
reference_text: majority of Rainier's forces were focused on disrupting the French occupation of Suez in the Red Sea. This diversion of British resources created gaps in the coverage in merchant shipping and Sercey was able to send the frigate Preneuse and corvette Brûle @-@ Gueule to Manila late in the year to join the repaired Spanish squadron. At the beginning of February 1799, this combined force sailed to Macau, taking the British defences by surprise. The British commander Captain William Hargood counterattacked, advancing on the Franco @-@ Spanish force which retreated during the day and disappeared under cover of darkness that evening in the Wanshan Archipelago. The combined squadron then dispersed and the China Fleet was not attacked again until the Battle of Pulo Aura in 1804, at which a French squadron was again driven off in confusion. The frigates Cooke had mimicked, Forte and Prudente were sent to operate independently against British trade in the Indian Ocean in early 1799. Prudente was captured by HMS Daedalus at the Action of 9 February 1799 near Southern Africa, and Forte was intercepted by HMS Sybille under Cooke on 28 February near Balasore in Bengal. In the ensuing battle Forte was captured but Cooke mortally wounded, dying on 25 May.

It was here that an artillery shell fell at 2.30am on the morning of 3 April, killing a corporal and wounding two others. The shock of the explosion was so great that no one thought to check the casualty list before going to bed. This did not go unnoticed by the staff, who began to receive reports of people in the Foothills who had been killed or mortally wounded by shrapnel. Within a few hours, there were so many casualties that ambulances were despatched to the area in droves. One of these was the Red Cross ambulance which made its way to Burntisland by nightfall. After dropping off the wounded, it set off on a 30 mile journey to Courcelette, some 200 miles away. There is no record of how many people were in the ambulance, but it is estimated that up to 1,000 people were taken to Courcelette that day. As the night wore on, the hospital became overcrowded and by the time it was opened the following morning, all the wounded had been transferred to more hospitable quarters.

Hammer was a major in the Household Cavalry and an ex-sergeant in the Territorial Army. He rose to the rank of major in 1885 and served in South Africa, New Zealand and the Falklands. His career spanned two world wars and a civil war in Rhodesia. On the latter occasion he helped quell a mutiny by Black Miners led by Tabeau Marceau. This would prove to be a turning point in the War of Retribution and set the stage for the Anglo-Zulu War.


At the outbreak of the Boer War in 1899-1900 there were over 3,000 Africans in the Transvaal, of whom more than half were under the age of twenty-five. As the war progressed this number swelled to a quarter of a million and by the end of the First World War it had risen to one million. These Afrikaners were divided into two warring factions, the Volkssturm and the Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP). The IFP took the lion's share of the spoils of the war, capturing large swathes of land and enslaving or slaughtering thousands of Afrikaners. Arnhem was a turning point in the Second World War. It marked the death knell of the Wehrmacht and the beginning of the United States of America's victory in the Pacific. As well as the loss of 1,735 Australian and New Zealand soldiers, an estimated 20,000 Japanese servicemen were killed in the battle. More than half of the battle's casualties were caused by artillery barrages, mortars and high explosive (HE) bombs. At the end of the battle, the enemy had no choice but to capitulate.

There was no attempt to recapture Arnhem, nor was there any question of retaking the port of Rotterdam, which was in the hands of the Japanese. In his memoirs, Winston Churchill referred to the battle as "the greatest of all battle honours which the gallant and indefatigable Australians have won in the war to end all wars".

Controls

Sonic controls like a run and jump game, with the exception of the Super Sonic and Knuckles spin dash moves. He can double jump, wall jump, and dive to the ground as well as turn in midair. In addition, Sonic can grab ledges and ladders, and is able to cling to walls for a short period of time. This is useful for traversing tight crevices, but be careful not to fall off the edge too many times, as it will deplete your life bar.

Speed Toggles

By pressing and holding the A button, you can toggle between Normal and Fast/Slower speeds. These speeds have different visual effects, ranging from rings changing color to an increase in speed. When speed is on, the music will be sped up, and enemies will get in your way. On the other hand, when speed is off, the music will be slowed down, and enemies will go by without a care in the world.

Aesthetics

Sonic the Hedgehog is a cel-shaded game, with pixel art-style graphics.

Ideas proposed to flesh out the character included placing him in a rock band, giving him vampire fangs, and giving him a human girlfriend named Madonna, but Sega of America scrapped these ideas to keep his identity simple. Sega of America also expressed concerns that most Americans would not know what a hedgehog is and initially proposed a full @-@ scale recreation of the character, but compromised with Sonic Team to simply make design changes. The antagonist ended up being named " Dr. Eggman " in Japan and " Dr. Robotnik " in other regions as a result of a dispute between Sega's American and Japanese divisions.

Sonic the Hedgehog (ソニック・ザ・ヘッジホッグ) is a video game character from the Sonic the Hedgehog series. He is the titular protagonist of the series, and one of the most popular characters in the franchise. Created by Naoto Ohshima, Sonic has appeared in a total of twenty-seventy-ninth videogames to date, which is more than any other character aside from Knuckles the Echidna. Despite his popularity, Sonic has never been able to make it to the top of the box office charts, due to the fact that he is an offbeat character to begin with. As of April 2018, Sonic has an estimated value of $1.05 billion according to valuations compiled by ValuePenguin. This makes him the fifteenth most valuable character in the world, a position he has held since his debut in 1991. [1]

Creation

Forrest Keikira-Ginsberg's story about Sonic's creation was the basis for the comic The Adventures of Sonic the Hedgehog, which was published in the United States by Archie Comics. Keikira-Ginsberg was a high school student in Hokkaido, Japan with a passion

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> With a satisfying protagonist completed, Sega turned to esteemed programmer Yuji Naka, who had impressed them through his work on Phantasy Star and the Genesis port
reference_text: of Ghouls'n Ghosts. The gameplay originated with a tech demo by Naka, who developed an algorithm allowing a sprite to move smoothly on a curve by determining its position with a dot matrix. Naka's prototype was a platform game with a fast @-@ moving character rolling in a ball through a long, winding tube, and this concept was fleshed out with Ohshima's character designs and levels by designer Hirokazu Yasuhara. Yasuhara originally intended to work on the game for three months due to the delay of his planned move to the United States by the outbreak of the Gulf War, but was engrossed in the project for nearly a year. His designs for levels were intended to attract both hardcore and casual gamers by integrating occasional challenging set pieces into the mostly accessible level design. The game's color scheme was influenced by the work of pop artist Eizin Suzuki, and the aesthetics of Green Hill were influenced by the geography of California.

One of the most influential games of the last decade and a half has been Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker. Developed by Kojima Productions, the game was met with critical acclaim and sold over 10 million copies, helping revitalize the Silent Hill series. However, many have wondered what went wrong with the game, and to this day no one knows the answer.

It's no secret that MGS:PW did not live up to the hype that surrounded it. For one, the game suffered from a lack of co-op, which resulted in players running into dead ends all over the map. Worse, the level design was atrocious, with every enemy you came across acting as a hindrance to your progress. On top of that, the game never got a release date, and Konami's PR and marketing departments kept stalling the game for months at a time.

Biography

Nakamura grew up in Aichi Prefecture, one of the most rural areas of Japan. His parents were in the service, and at the age of six he was sent to live with his grandparents for a few months. This was the first time he had seen a television, and in the years that followed he would spend every spare moment watching it. As a high school student, Nakamura studied computer science and began writing fanzines for Sega Megadrive and Dreamcast.[1] One of his most well-known works was a story based on the life of Mega Man's nemesis Dr. Wily, known as "Robot no Yabou" (探偵のようせ, lit. Robot Wily). This story was made into a two-part OVA in the summer of 1999, and the second part was released theatrically in October that year to critical acclaim.[2]

Sonic the Hedgehog came out in arcades in August of 1999, and quickly became a fan favorite. Soon after, an ad for the game appeared in Famitsu magazine, garnering the attention of Takashi Iizuka, who was looking for a band to compose music for his newly-launched video game company Compile Heart. Sega of America created a large @-@ scale marketing campaign to promote the game and Sonic as a mascot for the company.

A common theme in his work is that of an idyllic life, such as snow leopards, otters, penguins, polar bears, sea urchins, ewes, bunnies, foxes, raccoons, hares, kangaroos, owls, hawks, crows, ravens, vultures, etc. It is interesting to note that one of his most popular characters is the wolf from Metal Gear Solid (MGS for short). Gameplay

Sonic the Hedgehog takes place in a 2D sidescrolling world similar to that of the Super Mario Bros. series. The player controls Sonic, a speedster with the ability to jump, spin dash, and wall jump. There are a variety of enemies to deal with, including Robotnik's goons, Knuckles the Echidna, Chaotix, Spiked Troggs, Tails the Rail Gun Turret, Eggman's henchmen, and Dr. Eggman himself. In addition to these enemies, there are also power-ups that can be picked up and used to your advantage. One of these is the Chaos Emerald, which allows Sonic to turn into Super Sonic at will. When this happens, he is invulnerable to all attacks, but suffers a -2 to all stats for the duration of the transformation. Also, his speed is increased to 300 miles per hour (approx. 4.5 km/h), and he gains the ability to run on water without falling in. The Chao Garden is a part of the game, where the player can collect chao (reminiscent of fruit) and level up their Chao over time. Each Chao has a color, and

Sonic the Hedgehog became available on GameTap in September 2009. In October 2010, it was released as a Microsoft Windows download which was ported to Steam. The port features widescreen graphics, the optional ability to spin dash, a time attack mode, and the unlockable option to play as Tails or Knuckles the Echidna. Sales and Impressions

The game sold 1.5 million copies in its first year, an impressive number for a 16-bit game. As of 2006, there are over 100 emulators for the SNES, which allows players to play the game on a wide variety of systems. Some of the emulators are freeware, while others are subscription-based for a fee. For example, RetroArch is a free emulator that has been around since the mid-1990s, while Mupen64Plus is a subscription-based emulator that started in the summer of 2000. There's no need to get bogged down in the minutiae of the character's back story, though that's an important part of the Sonic mythos. What we're interested in is how he came to be the titular hero of the series, and what it means to live in a world where so many things are at stake.

Sonic's birth was a long time coming. At the time of the game's release, Sega was in shambles. The company had gone through a decade of mismanagement, and sales of its home console, the Mega Drive, were slumping. In an effort to shore up its faltering business, Sega of America CEO Michael Eisner took the reigns of the company, reorganizing it into a publicly traded company on the New York Stock Exchange. This was no small task, and it took three years to complete.

Eisner's goal was to bring Sega back to its heyday, when it was the undisputed leader in the arcades and one of the fastest growing companies in the world. By rebranding the company as Sega Enterprises, Eisner hoped to capitalize on the company's long-forgotten technology and market position. As one of the world's preeminent game

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The game's success led Sega to develop an extensive media franchise. A 1992 sequel, Sonic the Hedgehog 2, gave Sonic a best friend ( and
reference_text: sidekick ) named Miles " Tails " Prower and continued the fight against Dr. Robotnik. Sonic has generated dozens of additional games and a large cast of recurring characters ( keeping Sonic and Robotnik as mainstays ), surviving the end of Sega console manufacturing after the Dreamcast. The series has ventured from platformers to fighting, racing, role @-@ playing, and sports games, and has expanded into anime and manga, cartoons and comic books, novels, and toys. Sonic the Hedgehog has become one of the best @-@ selling video game franchises of all time, with over 150 million copies sold by May 2014. The game's first stage, Green Hill Zone, has also been re @-@ purposed for use in several other titles such as Sonic Adventure 2, Sonic Generations and the Super Smash Bros. series.

Rents in Greater Manchester are "out of control", according to a report which calls for a clampdown on over-renting.

The M.E.N. looked at house prices as well as council tax to find out how much people are paying for their homes.

There was a rise of £1,724 in the average house price in Greater Manchester between 2011 and 2015, compared with the UK average of £216,958.

Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham said the figures were "alarming".

Mr Burnham, who is standing for re-election in May, said: "I am concerned that we are on the brink of a housing crisis like the one we had in the 1980s and 1990s.

"It is an issue that needs to be addressed head on and not wait until it spirals out of control."

In an interview with Entertainment Weekly, Abrams explained, "I have a very specific vision of what needs to happen, and there's no room for improvisation at all. Every line is pre-written, and it's in the script like clockwork."

In Michigan, the highway runs through the UP in two segments as a part of the state trunkline highway system, entering the state at Ironwood and ending at St. Ignace ; in between, US 2 briefly traverses the state of Wisconsin. As one of the major transportation arteries in the UP, US 2 is a major conduit for traffic through the state and neighboring northern Midwest states. Two sections of the roadway are included as part of the Great Lakes Circle Tours, and other segments are listed as state @-@ designated Pure Michigan Byways. Traffic [ edit ]

Highway 2 is divided into two sections: I-90 in the north and I-90 in the south. There are tolls on both sections to pay for the construction of the highway. This has led to a series of lawsuits that have resulted in the state of Washington being reimbursed for the cost of the section, along with an additional $1.5 billion over the next 50 years. As of 2017, the number of vehicles traversing the highway has reached an all-time high of 5 million per day.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The route of what became US 2 was used as part of two Indian trails before European settlers came to the UP, and as part of the Michigan segments of
reference_text: the Theodore Roosevelt International Highway and the King's International Highway auto trails in the early 20th century. The state later included these trails as part of M ‑ 12 when the first state highway trunklines were designated in 1919. Most of M ‑ 12 was redesignated as part of US 2 when the US Highway System was created on November 11, 1926. Since the 1930s, several changes have reshaped the highway's routing through the UP. One such alteration eventually created a business loop that connected across the state line with Hurley, Wisconsin, and others pushed an originally inland routing of US 2 closer to the Lake Michigan shoreline. With the creation of the Interstate Highway System, part of US 2 was rerouted to coincide with the new Interstate 75 ( I ‑ 75 ), though in the 1980s, the U.S. Highway was truncated and removed from the I ‑ 75 freeway, resulting in today's basic form.

Railroad and Locomotive Trains

The first locomotive to run on the route was the Mackinaw H.M. No. 1, built in 1869. It was one of the first steam locomotives in the United States, and used compressed air to propel the caboose at speeds of 25 miles per hour. This was a breakthrough in the development of high-speed railroads, and set the stage for the more than 1,000 steam locomotives built in the United States and Canada up to the present day. After the Civil War, the number of steam locomotives began to decline, and they were replaced by trolleys in the 19th century. As far as can be determined, the track and power plant remains the same as it was in the mid-19th century. Today, the tracks are in good condition, and

It's a hot day in mid-summer, and I'm driving my Honda Ridgeline on Interstate 90, one of the most congested highways in the country. Traffic is snarled for miles, and every so often a tractor-trailer swerves into the oncoming lane, spilling its load of wood chips all over the road. This is the state of affairs that plagues I-90, which traverses the heart of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Seaway (GSLS for short). The US 2 highway was built in the 1960s to connect Lake Michigan to the Gulf of Mexico, but over the years it has become a lifeline for truckers hauling everything from sandblasting equipment to drywall for high-rise condominiums. For a second time in as many years, we're going to talk about traffic gridlock. That's no coincidence. There's a lot of talk about "traffic calming" these days, and not just in North America. The world's transportation planners are trying to figure out how to deal with ever-increasing numbers of cars on the road, and one of the solutions they're looking at is what's called multimodal transportation, which has its roots in the mid-20th century. Multimodal means that people can get from A to B without having to stop at every stop sign, bumper to bumper, as they do in congested cities like New York and San Francisco. This is good for public health, of course, but it's also good for economic development. By the 1970s, people were driving less and urban sprawl was on the wane. In the United States, car ownership went from 50 percent of the population in 1950 to less than 30 percent today. That's a lot of people who no longer need to rely on the freeways that crisscross the country. As a result, America's highways are in the enviable position of being able to do their job without too much interference from human beings. Now, some of

Construction [ edit ]

[3] In order to provide a route for the railroad, the U.S. government began surveying the land west of the Rocky Mountains and, in 1891, issued a patent for the right to do so. The United States Geological Survey (USGS) was charged with the task of carrying out the survey, which took several years. At the time, there were no plans for a railroad in the Great Plains, and the railroads did not seem likely to be built any time soon. This proved to be a miscalculation, as the railroad had the potential to revolutionize the transportation of goods and people between the East and West Coasts of the United States.

On 1 January 1892, President Grover Cleveland signed the Homestead Act into law, which allowed anyone who owned land up to 200 acres to homestead without paying market value. Within a year, thousands of land speculators flocked to the prairie, taking advantage of the newly freed up land. Some of the most well-known were John D. Rockefeller, J.P. Morgan, Cornelius Vanderbilt, and Andrew Carnegie. By the end of the year, more than one million acres had

In 1961, another new freeway segment closed the gap between the Mackinac Bridge and Evergreen Shores sections. At its peak, traffic backed up for miles every day to get to and from the state capital of Lansing. This became known as the "traffic jam" and resulted in hundreds of arrests for vagrancy.

As time went on, the tollbooths grew in size and began to encroach on the right of way. It was decided to take care of the problem by erecting a tollbooth on the side of the road in front of the house of each car that passed through the tollbooth. If the car did not pay the toll, it would be towed to the nearest police station and impounded. By the 1930s, the tollbooths were no longer needed and, according to the U.S. Department of Transportation, there were no records of anyone being towed as a result of nonpayment.

This decision was based on input from the public, members of the State Historic Preservation Office, as well as a review of the project's environmental impact statement (EIS).

What is the status of the Upper Twin Falls Bridge?

The Upper Twin Falls Bridge is in the final stages of construction and is expected to be completed in mid-summer 2014. Work has been completed on the bridge abutments, retaining walls, pilings, piers, culverts, and drainage ditches. Crews are making final preparations for anchoring the bridge to the bottom of the Menominee River. As of the date of this publication, there are no permits in place to move the bridge in any direction.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Before 1983, US 2 used a different routing through Manistique and crossed the Manistique River on what is nicknamed the " Siphon Bridge "
reference_text: Built as a part of a raceway flume on the river, the water level is actually higher than the road surface. This produces a siphon effect, giving the bridge its nickname. The Manistique Pulp and Paper Company was organized in 1916 and needed a dam on the Manistique River to supply their mill. This dam would require a large section of the city to be flooded, and shallow river banks meant difficulties in any bridge construction. Instead of expensive dikes, a concrete tank was built lengthwise in the river bed ; the sides of this tank provided man @-@ made banks higher than the natural banks. The Michigan Works Progress Administration described the bridge as having " concrete bulkheads, formed by the side spans of the bridge, [ that ] allow the mill to maintain the water level several feet above the roadbed. " The Manistique Tourism Council stated : " At one time, the bridge itself was partially supported by the water that was atmospherically forced under it, " and that the bridge has been featured in Ripley's Believe It or Not!. The eight @-@ span structure is 294 feet ( 90 m ) long.

So what's the deal with the routing of US 2? According to the Minnesota Department of Transportation (MDOT), which administers the interstate system, the Interstate Highways Act of 1887 called for a two-pronged approach to interstates: 1) north-south (N-S) and 2) east-west (E-W). This resulted in the creation of the U.S. Routes that we know today, in an attempt to reduce bottlenecks and traffic snarls that were the bane of road construction in the pre-automobile era.

From 1892, a portable steam engine was used as auxiliary power, driving an extra pair of millstones on the ground floor. This was replaced in 1914 by a Hornsby oil engine. Bryant ran the mill until 1920 when he sold it to Alphonso Vincent, a retired millwright from Garboldisham, Norfolk. The Hornsby engine was sold in the early 1920s. The mill was tailwinded c1920, and as a result one pair of sails was removed. Vincent carried out some repairs to the mill and ran it until he retired in 1924. One of the remaining two sails was wrecked in 1926 when the mill was again tailwinded.

By the 1880s, the boom in lumber had reached a fever pitch, thanks to the opening of the Transcontinental Railroad in 1869 and the California Gold Rush in 1848. Thousands of Californians flocked to the Sierra Nevada foothills to work the sawmills, log cabins, and canneries that sprawled across the land like spiderwebs. In less than a decade, California's lumber industry boomed from a little more than 1,000 trees per hectare to an all-time high of 2,566 trees per hectare. This was no small feat, considering that the state's tree densities were in the single digits as recently as the Civil War. To make matters worse, there was a scarcity of lumber in the Pacific Northwest, which put pressure on California's already overcrowded harvests. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Four work @-@ ins were held during 1984. The first two were by apprentices from Eastern Electricity Board. Thelnetham Windmill was chosen at
reference_text: the project to benefit from the Young Person's Development Project for that year. Pakenham Watermill had previously benefited from the project, and its owners, the Suffolk Preservation Trust, had suggested that Thelnetham Windmill would be a good candidate for the scheme. Two separate parties spent a week each at the mill. A mains electricity supply was provided. An underground cable was laid with assistance from British Telecom who were trialling a thrust borer which had been developed at their research facility at Martlesham Heath. The thrust borer laid 25 yards ( 23 m ) of ducting through which the mains cable was pulled into position. The mill was then supplied with lights and sockets on each floor.

On the night of the fourth @-@ ins, there was a firecracker and one of the windows of the workhouse was broken. In the morning, the police were called to the works for a report of rioting. No one was arrested.

An inquest was held in February 1985 and the Coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death. This was based on the fact that the body was found in a pool of blood next to the carriageway that led to the works. It was ruled that the man had been strangled to death by ligature marks on his neck.

After the inquest, the Workhouse Inspectorate carried out a re-examination of the cause of death. They found that the lanyard used to fasten the man's cravat to the windmill did not have a knot in it. This, they said, was the killer. The lanyard was made of hemp and had the letter 'A' embossed on it. As a result, the workhouse was fined £5,000 for not having a certificate of fit for work.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Off @-@ site, the new brake wheel and fantail were made. The original brake wheel was too rotten to repair, and showed evidence that it
reference_text: had been altered from the original one installed in 1819. The original brake wheel was 6 feet ( 1 @.@ 83 m ) diameter to allow the Common sails to run at their optimum speed. When the mill was modernised in 1832 it was necessary to alter the gear ratios within the mill, as Patent sails run at a slower speed than Common sails. The great spur wheel was increased in diameter and the stone nuts reduced in diameter. The brake wheel was also rebuilt, with a cast iron segment ring fitted in place of the original cogs, resulting in a wheel 7 feet 2 inches ( 2 @.@ 18 m ) in diameter. The opinion of professional millwrights was sought, and it was decided that a scaled @-@ up version of the original brake wheel would be made, but retaining the cast iron teeth segments. The remains of the original brake wheel were retained as an exhibit in the mill. The original iron segments were all broken, so a pattern was made and new segments were cast in heat @-@ treated malleable cast iron. When the brake wheel was completed it was dismantled and transported to the mill ready for reassembly.

Restoration & Renovation in the 1980s/90s [ edit ]

Main article: Restoration & Renovation in the 1980s/90s

As time went on, the building became dilapidated and unkempt. To add to the disrepair, asbestos was used in the chimney flues and fireplaces due to the heat they put out. There were problems with water seeping into the basement and a lack of maintenance resulted in mould growing all over the building. At one point an alarm was tripped in the middle of the night that people were having epileptic fits and police were called to the scene. On the ground floor, two elevators were inoperable for no apparent reason. This was rectified by installing a power substation, but the problem lingered. By the mid-1990s, the heating system was no longer working and, apart from that, the building was in a shambles. In order to save money, plans were made to demolish the building and build a car park on the site. These plans were scuppered by the financial crisis of 2008/9 and the cost of renovating the building was prohibitive. It was decided to carry on with the refurbishment, but with a focus on the interior rather than the exterior. Some

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Fighting between Aborigines and Europeans was localised as the Aborigines did not form confederations capable of sustained resistance. As a result, there
reference_text: was not a single war, but rather a series of violent engagements and massacres across the continent. Organised or disorganised however, a pattern of frontier warfare emerged with Aboriginal resistance beginning in the 18th century and continuing into the early 20th century. This warfare contradicts the popular and at times academic " myth " of peaceful settlement in Australia. Faced with Aboriginal resistance settlers often reacted with violence, resulting in a number of indiscriminate massacres. Among the most famous is the Battle of Pinjarra in Western Australia in 1834. Such incidents were not officially sanctioned however, and after the Myall Creek massacre in New South Wales in 1838 seven Europeans were hanged for their part in the killings. However, in Tasmania the so @-@ called Black War was fought between 1828 and 1832, and aimed at driving most of the island's native inhabitants onto a number of isolated peninsulas. Although it began in failure for the British, it ultimately resulted in considerable casualties amongst the native population.

Etymology and etymology of the word [ edit ]

It is unclear who coined the term, but it was popularised by William Hogarth in his 1837 painting The Dying Gaul, which depicts a band of Europeans trying to subdue an Aborigine by shooting arrows at him. The French-born Hogarth was a well-known caricaturist and illustrator of children's books, and his use of the term may have been influenced by the title of a book by Pierre Choderlos de Laclos, De l'Inde ou la Guerre Française (The Indian or the War of Freedom or the Guerrilla War in France). According to an Oxford English Dictionary entry, the term "flamenco" means "musical flute" in Spanish, and refers to a type of music that originated in Buenos Aires, Argentina before spreading to other parts of Latin America by emigrants fleeing the Spanish Civil War. This, combined with the similarity of the word Flamenco to the Spanish word fraternidad, or brotherhood, gives credence to the theory that the term was in use at the time of the First World War.[2]

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> From 1870 until 1901, each of the six colonial governments was responsible for their own defence. The colonies had gained responsible government between 1855 and 1890, and
reference_text: while the Colonial Office in London retained control of some affairs, the Governor of the each colony was required to raise their own colonial militia. To do this, they were granted the authority from the British crown to raise military and naval forces. Initially these were militias in support of British regulars, but when military support for the colonies ended in 1870, the colonies assumed their own defence responsibilities. The colonial military forces included unpaid volunteer militia, paid citizen soldiers, and a small permanent component. They were mainly infantry, cavalry and mounted infantry, and were neither housed in barracks nor subject to full military discipline. Even after significant reforms in the 1870s — including the expansion of the permanent forces to include engineer and artillery units — they remained too small and unbalanced to be considered armies in the modern sense. By 1885, the forces numbered 21 @,@ 000 men. Although they could not be compelled to serve overseas many volunteers subsequently did see action in a number conflicts of the British Empire during the 19th century, with the colonies raising contingents to serve in Sudan, South Africa and China.

There were, however, two areas of treaty-making that were not dealt with at the time of the colonies' accession to the Commonwealth: the question of self-defence and the sovereignty of the Crown. As far as self-defence was concerned, the United Kingdom did not take a position on the use of force to defend the colonies from invasion, but agreed to co-operate with the colonisation of South Africa, Malaya, Ceylon and Mauritius. For the Crown, sovereignty was of paramount importance, and it was this that led to the signing of the Concordat of 1763. This codified the prerogatives of the Crown as Head of the Commonwealth of Nations, and gave the Crown the right to make treaties and engage in peacekeeping operations without the consent of the other signatories.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Despite a reputation of colonial inferiority, many of the locally raised units were highly organised, disciplined, professional, and well trained. During this period, defences
reference_text: in Australia mainly revolved around static defence by combined infantry and artillery, based on garrisoned coastal forts. However, by the 1890s, improved railway communications between the mainland eastern colonies led Major General James Edwards — who had recently completed a survey of colonial military forces — to the belief that the colonies could be defended by the rapid mobilisation of brigades of infantry. As a consequence he called for a restructure of defences, and defensive agreements to be made between the colonies. Edwards argued for the colonial forces to be federated and for professional units — obliged to serve anywhere in the South Pacific — to replace the volunteer forces. These views found support in the influential New South Wales Commandant, Major General Edward Hutton, however suspicions held by the smaller colonies towards New South Wales and Victoria stifled the proposal. These reforms remaining unresolved however, and defence issues were generally given little attention in the debate on the political federation of the colonies.

The Battle of Cannae (332 BC) was a turning point in Roman history. At the head of a coalition of Carthaginian and Seleucid allies, Hannibal crossed the Rubicon River in an attempt to gain control of the Isthmus of Corinth, which bisected the Gallic heartland. This had been the Achilles heel of the Roman Republic for three centuries, and its capture would have dealt a death blow to the power of Rome. It was, however, held by the consul Publius Cornelius Scipio, who fought his way to the top of the precipice by sheer force of arms. Scipio's victory was marred by treachery on the part of Cinna, the tribune of the plebs, who took it upon himself to declare Hannibal persona non grata (out of the city without a permit). In the confusion that followed, two legions were ambushed and decimated, resulting in the death of over 1,000 men. After this ignominious defeat, Hannibal set his sights on Rome itself, and on October 31, 332 BC, he began his siege of the city.

Background Edit

Forced to fight for their lives, the British Expeditionary Force (BEF) was in shambles after months of indecision and mismanagement. At the head of the war effort was Brigadier-General Gwyn Morritt, who had come to command the 3rd Armoured Division in December 1899. Morritt's task was to reorganise the BEF into a well-oiled fighting machine by the end of the year, and this turned out to be a Herculean task. As well as re-equipping the Divisions, Morritt set about the task of building fortifications around the front so that the troops could stay in place rather than running away to regroup. These defences were known as Cemeteries, and consisted of barbed wire entanglements strung across the battlefield. Each Cemetery was manned by a company of Territorials, whose job was to shoot to kill anyone attempting to cross the barricades. If an enemy soldier got the drop on the Tommies, they were shot without hesitation. It was this approach that resulted in the death of over one hundred and fifty Beafreaks during the Battle of Ypres.[1]

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Prior to federation each self @-@ governing colony had operated its own naval force. These navies were small and lacked blue water capabilities, forcing the separate
reference_text: colonies to subsidise the cost of a British naval squadron in their waters for decades. The colonies maintained control over their respective navies until 1 March 1901, when the Commonwealth Naval Force was created. This new force also lacked blue water capable ships, and ultimately did not lead to a change in Australian naval policy. In 1907 Prime Minister Alfred Deakin and Creswell, while attending the Imperial Conference in London, sought the British Government's agreement to end the subsidy system and develop an Australian navy. The Admiralty rejected and resented the challenge, but suggested diplomatically that a small fleet of destroyers and submarines would be sufficient. Deakin was unimpressed, and in 1908 invited the American Great White Fleet to visit Australia. This visit fired public enthusiasm for a modern navy and in part led to the order of two 700 @-@ ton River @-@ class destroyers. The surge in German naval construction prompted the Admiralty to change their position however and the Royal Australian Navy was subsequently formed in 1911, absorbing the Commonwealth Naval Force. On 4 October 1913, the new fleet steamed through Sydney Heads, consisting of the battlecruiser HMAS Australia, three light cruisers, and three destroyers, while several other ships were still under construction. And as a consequence the navy entered the First World War as a formidable force.

Prof Peter Higgs, emeritus professor of physics at Edinburgh University, said: "My heart is bursting with joy."

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> From the 1920s Australia's defence thinking was dominated by British Imperial defence policy, which was embodied by the " Singapore strategy ". This strategy involved the
reference_text: construction and defence of a major naval base at Singapore from which a large British fleet would respond to Japanese aggression in the region. To this end, a high proportion of Australian forces in Asia were concentrated in Malaya during 1940 and 1941 as the threat from Japan increased. However, as a result of the emphasis on co @-@ operation with Britain, relatively few Australian military units had been retained in Australia and the Asia @-@ Pacific region. Measures were taken to improve Australia's defences as war with Japan loomed in 1941, but these proved inadequate. In December 1941, the Australian Army in the Pacific comprised the 8th Division, most of which was stationed in Malaya, and eight partially trained and equipped divisions in Australia. The RAAF was equipped with 373 aircraft, most of which were obsolete trainers, and the RAN had three cruisers and two destroyers in Australian waters.

Singapore was one of the most militarised cities in the world, with a population of 5,000,000 at the time of the Japanese invasion in 1942. There were no gun emplacements, armoured car depots or fortifications on the island, apart from a railway station at Batam, which was taken by the Japanese without a fight. As a result, the Japanese did not feel the need to make Singapore their staging post for landings in the Malay Peninsula. In any case, the war was going badly for the Japanese, and they were in no hurry to get bogged down in a defence of Singapore.


It was an open secret that the Japanese had no intention of fighting a war of national liberation in Southeast Asia. To that end, and for reasons that are obvious to anyone who has studied the history of the Pacific War, the Japanese sought to establish a garrison and protectorate in Singapore, rather than embark on a full-scale invasion of the Malay Peninsula. By mid-1943, General Yamashita had set up a command post in Singapore, and on the 23rd of that month Japanese troops landed en masse on the island. Within a few weeks, all resistance had been dislodged, and Singapore was under Japanese control.

Leyte Gulf has been described as the bloodiest battle in the history of the Pacific War. More than a million casualties were recorded, making it the most bloodcurdling battle to take place in the Far East up to that time. As well as the death toll, an estimated 50,000 Japanese soldiers were killed in the fighting. There were at least two US destroyers sunk and one torpedoed by Japanese torpedoes. On the Australian side, 1,531 servicemen lost their lives, of whom 437 were aircrew.

The war was in its eleventh month when the battle broke out. General Douglas MacArthur, commander of the U.S. forces in the Pacific, had decided to go to war without waiting for the surrender of Japan. In his memoirs, Macarthur wrote that he was "deeply impressed by the ferocity of the Japanese and their unyielding determination to win the war by any means at their disposal." It was a time of war when every inch of territory was contested, and the Japanese were determined to keep it that way.

By mid-1944, Australia had a force of 1,845 men under arms, an all-time high. At the Battle of Tarawa, which took place on 21 December 1944, there were about 20,000 servicemen on the island of Tarawa, of whom more than a third were Australian. In the months and years that followed, it became clear that the fighting was no longer going to be close, either in terrain or numbers. As well as being one of the bloodiest battles of the Pacific War, Tarawa was a turning point in the history of the Australian Army.

For more than a year, Australian troops had laboured in the jungles of Leyte, Palawan, Formosa and Iwo Jima, battling Japanese forces to the death. Their task was to hold the beachheads against the advance of the Japanese, while inflicting as much damage as possible on the enemy landing craft (LCCs) that ferried troops and supplies to the beaches. This was the first time that amphibious operations had been used in the Pacific, and it was an audacious and highly successful way of fighting a war.

History [ edit ]

Prior to the declaration, there was no government in Malaya, a self-governing colony of the British Empire. The British had ceded the colony to the newly formed People's Republic of Malaya (PRM) in the Treaty of Nansha Ratanakosin (1948), which was signed on 1 January 1948. As a result, the government was no longer dependent on the British for defence and could act independently in matters of foreign policy. This, in turn, led to a rise in anti-communist sentiment in the United Kingdom, which was concerned that the Communists would gain ascendancy in the PRM.

Campbell began his speech by emphasising the need for "stability and peaceful co-existence" in the island, and called on the British government to take steps to bring about this. He went on to say that Australia stood ready to assist the British government in any way it could, including financial assistance.[1]

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Australian ground forces were deployed to Malaya in October 1955 as part of the Far East Strategic Reserve. In January 1956, the first Australian ground forces were deployed
reference_text: on Malaysian peninsula, consisting of the 2nd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment ( 2 RAR ). 2 RAR mainly participated in " mopping up " operations over the next 20 months, conducting extensive patrolling in and near the CT jungle bases, as part of 28th British Commonwealth Brigade. Contact with the enemy was infrequent and results small, achieving relatively few kills. 2 RAR left Malaysia October 1957 to be replaced by 3 RAR. 3 RAR underwent six weeks of jungle training and began driving MCP insurgents back into the jungle of Perak and Kedah. The new battalion extensively patrolled and was involved in food denial operations and ambushes. Again contact was limited, although 3 RAR had more success than its predecessor. By late 1959, operations against the MCP were in their final phase, and most communists had been pushed back and across the Thailand border. 3 RAR left Malaysia October 1959 and was replaced by 1 RAR. Though patrolling the border 1 RAR did not make contact with the insurgents, and in October 1960 it was replaced by 2 RAR, which stayed in Malaysia until August 1963. The Malayan Emergency officially ended on 31 July 1960.

History Edit

Origins Edit

The Boat Race was created in 1894 by Lord Lytton-Macleod, a well-known rower of the time. As an act of charity, he set up a race between two universities, Oxford and St Edmund Hall, to raise money for the war effort. This proved to be a resounding success, and over the years it has grown into a much larger event than it was originally intended to be. For more information on the history of the Boat Race, see the Oxford Historical Society's page on the Boat Race.

Organisational and Sponsorship Edit

The Boat Race is the brainchild of the Oxford Dictatorship, a non-profit organisation that seeks to promote inter-university camaraderie and good sportsmanship. They do this by organising boat races every year, along with social events such as polo matches and picnics. Since its

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Oxford were pre @-@ race favourites, but Cambridge won the toss and elected to start from the Surrey station. Oxford took an early lead, but the
reference_text: boats closed on each other, and Umpire John Garrett was forced to issue a number of warnings to both coxes in an attempt to prevent a collision. By Craven Cottage, Oxford were nearly a length ahead and Cambridge responded ; by the time the crews passed under Hammersmith Bridge they were level. Along Chiswick Eyot Oxford moved ahead once again, and were clear of Cambridge after 30 strokes. Oxford extended their lead to pass the finishing post in 20 minutes 53 seconds, six lengths and 22 seconds ahead of their opponents. Driving rain, strong winds and choppy water resulted in the slowest winning time for over sixty years, but the largest margin of victory since the 2004 race.

History

Early Settlers

According to Wikipedia, the Cherokee began inhabiting the Black Hills as early as 1750, but it was not until 1832 that they came into contact with the United States of America. At that time, the territory was known as the Shawnee Nation, and consisted of present-day South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, and Texas. In 1832, President Andrew Jackson signed the Treaty of Sandusky, which ceded the Black Hills to the United States for $15 million in gold and 18,000 acres of land in perpetuity. As a result of this treaty, the Cherokee were no longer required to pay taxes, and no longer had to live in the reservation they had been living on for 200 years.

Aboriginal Traits

One of the most notable traits of the Cherokee is their belief in reincarnation. This belief is reflected in their word for "sun" (Cherokee sunwaw), which means "heaven" in their language. reference_text: -@ champion Samoa Joe and the challengers Booker T, Christian Cage, Rhino, and Robert Roode. In a King of the Mountain match, the objective is to climb a ladder and hang the championship belt on a hook above the ring. In order to do so, a wrestler must first qualify by either pinning or making another wrestler submit in the match. A wrestler who is pinned or made to submit is this placed in a penalty box for two minutes. The match is fought under no disqualification rules. Booker T was the first to qualify by pinning Rhino after slamming him back @-@ first into the mat with his signature Book End maneuver. Rhino was this placed in the penalty box. Roode was the next to qualify after bashing a ladder Cage held with a chair into him and following with a pin. Immediately afterwards, Rhino pinned Roode with a roll @-@ up pin to qualify. Later, Joe held Booker T in his signature Coquina Clutch submission hold when Cage ascended a padded turnbuckle and jumped off onto Booker T and Joe. He followed by pinning Booker T to qualify and send Booker T to the penalty box. When Booker T was released from the box, he attacked Nash with the title belt and then attempted to hang it. Nash stopped him and then dropped Booker T back @-@ first against the mat with his signature Jackknife Powerbomb maneuver. Joe was the last to qualify by pinning Roode after slamming him back and neck @-@ first into the mat with his signature Muscle Buster maneuver. Joe then hung the title belt at 19 minutes and 49 seconds to win the competition.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Home Made Mince Pie is a 1910 American silent short comedy produced by the Thanhouser Company. The film is a comedy of circumstances, in which
reference_text: the Gale family is going to host a dinner. The focus of the humor is in a mince pie that brandy is added to in an attempt to make it more appreciable, but three people each add brandy to the pie. Everyone becomes tipsy upon eating the pie, including the family cat, and the film concludes. No cast or staff credits for this film are known. The film was released on September 27, 1910, to mixed reviews in trade publications. Reviewers mentioned that the film was too long and it was unbelievable that one pie split eight ways would be able to impact everyone. The film is presumed lost.

Plot Synopsis Edit

An ex-convict gets a job as a janitor at a boarding house, unaware that the house is filled with burglars. One of the intruders sneaks into the house by posing as a bellwether to see if there is anyone in the house at a certain time. In the middle of the night, the alarm goes off, and the gang is on the prowl. Their aim is to steal the money stashed in the cupboards, but it is no easy task, as the door is locked from the inside. After a few mishaps, they manage to gain entry without arousing suspicion. Once inside, they make their way to the kitchen, where they have no trouble snatching a pot of mince pies. With the money in their pockets, they set off to do their robbery in broad daylight.

The Gales thought well of this established feature. They made it a joyous occasion for themselves as well as their guests. They were hardly an overly wealthy family, and their table was never notable for an oversupply of the good things of life, but whenever they gave a dinner they cast all thoughts of economy to the country winds and worked to the one end that their guests have a pleasant time. "

Gale Haggard is a character in Scrubs. She is Phoebe's babysitter and one of the most well-known characters on the show. Her catchphrase is "What's up, hombre?" (referencing the word "homosexual" in Spanish).

Biography Edit

Childhood Edit

Gale grew up in Las Vegas, Nevada, where she was an only child. At the age of six, she developed a stutter and went to a speech therapist to learn how to speak fluently. This was the beginning of her stuttering, which continued to get worse in high school. After graduating from high school, she dropped out to work as a stripper on the Gold Nugget Motel for a year and a half. The next year, she got a job at McDonald's, and by the time she was twenty-one, she had two part-time jobs and was living on her own.

reference_text: while writing scripts for the Thanhouser productions. The film director is unknown, but it may have been Barry O 'Neil. Film historian Q. David Bowers does not attribute a cameraman for this production, but at least two possible candidates exist. Blair Smith was the first cameraman of the Thanhouser company, but he was soon joined by Carl Louis Gregory who had years of experience as a still and motion picture photographer. The role of the cameraman was uncredited in 1910 productions. The cast credits are unknown, but many 1910 Thanhouser productions are fragmentary. In late 1910, the Thanhouser company released a list of the important personalities in their films. The list includes G.W. Abbe, Justus D. Barnes, Frank H. Crane, Irene Crane, Marie Eline, Violet Heming, Martin J. Faust, Thomas Fortune, George Middleton, Grace Moore, John W. Noble, Anna Rosemond, Mrs. George Walters. A surviving film still gives the possibility of identifying eight actors.

Plot Synopsis Edit

A week after the Battle of Midway, U.S. forces continue to lose ground to the Japanese. In the South Pacific, the island of Rabaul is recaptured by the Japanese, which results in the death of Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto. His will is found by Rear Admiral Shigemitsu Homma, who takes it to the Admiralty as evidence of Yamamoto's treachery. Homma intends to use the will to gain admiral rank and a knighthood, but before he can do so, an assassination attempt is made on his life. The conspirators are none other than Lt. Cmdr. Toshiaki Kurita and his right-hand man, Lt. Comdr. Keiichiro Sasaki. Both have been loyal to Ishikawa ever since the latter defected to the United States of America (USA) in 1894. Their plan is to blow up the bridge that leads to the battleship Yamato, which is moored in Rabaul harbor. This would be the first step in assassinating the admiral and becoming the de facto power in the Pacific. As a result, the USA declares war on Japan and all Japanese forces in the Pacific are ordered to surrender without delay.

In the mid-1970s, Rolling Stone editor Jann Wenner wrote an article for the magazine about John Lennon's The Beatles Anthology (which Starr co-produced with Ringo Starr in the late 1970s and early 1980s). The article focused on the cover of the Anthology, which was a collage of Starr's artworks, such as an American flag made of toilet paper, a black and white photograph of George Harrison looking dazed and dishevelled, and a still from the music video for "Paperback Writer" (originally sung by Eric Clapton). Wenner pointed out that the cover did not appear in the book, and called it "astonishingly unoriginal in its own right."[1]

With no one in the house to share the demo with, The Edge recalls dancing around and punching the air in celebration.

Horrible Bosses is a third-person point and click adventure game about a team of misfits trying to take down a supervillain by any means necessary. The game starts like any other, with you running around aimlessly shooting bad guys for no reason. But that's where the similarities end. First of all, you're in control of an amnesiac androgynous character named Delsin Rowe, who finds himself inexplicably teleported to a post-apocalyptic dystopia known as Acheron. From there, there's a lot of backtracking to get to the end of the game, and not a lot of dialogue to speak of. What's more, every boss is a fully fledged level with its own set of skills, which makes it difficult to figure out what to do at any given time. In other words, it's a slow, torturous deathtrap filled with uncoordinated ninjas wearing bandannas made of duct tape.

Editing Edit

There are a number of changes made to the film as it was re-edited for theatres. Among these are the removal of a scene where Jax goes to the morgue to look for Carradine's body, along with an editing change that makes it seem as though Tyrese is the aggressor in the carjacking.[1]

The soundtrack is a 2-disc set released on September 21, 2010. In addition to the film's soundtrack, the set includes audio commentary by director David Michôd and cinematographer John Seale, as well as a behind-the-scenes featurette on the making of the film.

New Line was reported to be negotiating with Gordon to return as director, with Bateman, Day, and Sudeikis also expected to return to their roles. On February 27, 2012, it was confirmed that Goldstein and Daley were in the process of writing the new script. In March 2013, Goldstein and Daley confirmed that they had submitted multiple draft scripts for the sequel, and that production had moved towards finalizing the budget. Later in the same month Bateman, Day, and Sudeikis were confirmed to be reprising their roles, with Foxx negotiating to return. The film will again be produced by Brett Ratner and Jay Stern. In August 2013, it was announced that Gordon would not be returning to direct because of scheduling conflicts and that the studio was actively searching for a replacement. In September 2013, Sean Anders was announced as Gordon's replacement, with John Morris joining the production as a producer. The pair had previously performed a rewrite on Goldstein's and Daley's sequel script. Filming had been scheduled to begin in summer 2013, but began in November 2013. Foxx, Jennifer Aniston, and Kevin Spacey reprised their roles, with Christoph Waltz and Chris Pine joining the cast.

NEW YORK — An all-white jury deliberated for less than two hours before convicting more than a dozen co-conspirators of racketeering as early as the 1980s, The Enquirer has learned.

The conviction could set a precedent for civil rights cases across the country, experts say. Jurors in the New York case were white, as were the jury foreman, defense attorney and assistant U.S. attorney who prosecuted the case.

Jurors had to decide whether there was enough evidence to convict each defendant of racketeering conspiracy, which carries a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison. If convicted, the defendants could have faced the death penalty.

It's unclear how many cases similar to the one in New York have been brought in the past, but at least one high-profile case is under review by the Justice Department. Last year, President Barack Obama commuted the sentences of 46 federal inmates, including one who was convicted of selling crack cocaine to an undercover Drug Enforcement Administration agent.

It was an odd way to start the day, but not the strangest thing that happened over the next two and a half years.

That's because on the morning of April 22, 1986, President Ronald Reagan's limousine was rear-ended by a sport utility vehicle on the George Washington Bridge in New York. The impact tore a hole in the driver's side, and Reagan was thrown from the vehicle. At the time, police were investigating whether Reagan had been drugged, and that may have been the reason he suffered a heart attack and lapsed into a coma.

Reagan, who was in his second term as president, survived the accident, but two days later, he was admitted to St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y., where he remained for a week. During that time, news reports began to surface that something was amiss with the president's health. In the days that followed, there were unconfirmed reports that Reagan had taken amphetamines, the anti-anxiety drug Valium and barbiturates, a sedative that slows breathing. Some of the drugs were in his intravenous (IV) catheter, which was surgically removed the following day.

By the time Reagan made his first public appearance after the accident, the public had no idea what to make of the man who had served as

Carol Matthews grew up in St. Louis, Missouri, the daughter of a well-known civil rights lawyer. She graduated from Wellesley College in the early 1960s, studied law at New York University, and clerked for Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall. In the summer of 1969, she got a job as a paralegal at the Public Defender Service of New York, where she helped indigent clients navigate the criminal justice system. One of her clients was Mark Hofmann, a chemical engineer who made LSD for the Grateful Dead. At the time, Hofmann was under investigation by the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), which was concerned that LSD was being used to manufacture amphetamines and, more worryingly, a hallucinogen called PCP.

Biography

Early life

Graves was born in St. Croix, a United States Virgin Islands territory, to a family of U.S. servicemen. His father, an Air Force lieutenant colonel, was killed in a plane crash while on a training mission to Grenada in the Caribbean. Shortly after his father's death, Graves learned martial arts from his mother, and at the age of six or seven went to live with his stepfather for a few months. It was during this time that Graves began to develop a love for kung fu, much to the chagrin of his stepfather. (AUDIO: Out of the Frying Pan)

The Eighth Doctor and Romana II had a run-in with Graves on Gallifrey in 2999. (PROSE: Remembrance of the Daleks)

Premise Edit

John McClane (Bruce Willis) is a Special Forces operative in the Middle East fighting Osama bin Laden's Al-Qaeda terrorist network. At the end of the film, McClane receives a text message from his wife, Holly (Sienna Miller), telling him that they have been married for twenty years. This is the last time the audience will see McClane on screen, except for a montage of news footage that ends the film.

Director Paul Greengrass told Movieline in an interview that one of the inspirations for the film was Saving Private Ryan (1998), a World War II film about the Battle of Arnhem in the Netherlands. [1] According to the press release, there were "several things that went into the decision to go with war as the backdrop rather than, say, a car chase" such as the death of General Creighton Abrams (Walter Matthau) in the film The Deer Hunter (1978), which was based on Michael Crichton's novel Catch-22 (1979).
