Although the base is portrayed in the film as a US base, all the aircraft and personnel in the scene are British in real life. In the film, Switchblades ( one @-@ person gliders resembling fighter jets in shape ) are flown by Bond and Jinx to stealthily enter North Korea. The Switchblade was based on a workable model called " PHASST " ( Programmable High Altitude Single Soldier Transport ). Kinetic Aerospace Inc.'s lead designer, Jack McCornack was impressed by director Lee Tamahori's way of conducting the Switchblade scene and commented, " It's brief, but realistic. The film crew set up a crane to hoist a C-130 Hercules in the middle of the airfield, which served as the home of the 7th Airlift Wing.

The helicopter was painted in the insignia of the United States Air Force (USAF) and fitted with a loudspeaker so crew members could communicate with the ground crew.

On the ground, there were about a dozen or so US servicemen and an equally large number of South Korean airmen working on the construction of the Hangar #1.

After filming was completed, the USAF took over the hangar and turned it into a command post for the Korean War.

According to Wikipedia, the base was decommissioned in the 1970s to make way for a golf course.

Directed by Sam Mendes, the film chronicles the plot of Ian Fleming's James Bond novel Goldfinger, starring Daniel Craig as 007. In the film, Bond is asked to take part in a high-stakes heist that goes wrong, and his nemesis Ernst Stavro Blofeld (Liam Neeson) kidnaps M (Naomie Harris) and Dr Madeleine Swann (Jessica Biel). Stavro intends to use the diamond known as the Philosopher's Stone to become immortal, but Bond has other plans.

Bond infiltrates the villain's hideout, only to find it full of henchmen armed with AK-47s and mortars. Despite the odds, Bond manages to outflank the bad guys and make his way to the top of the skyscraper by parachuting from a helicopter. Once there, Bond faces off against Blofeld in a climactic fistfight, during which one of the most iconic images in film history is set to play out.

This is the first time we get to see the action-packed opening sequence in all its glory, and it's worth revisiting every now and then to relive the exhilarating thrill of being a Bond fan. Check out the video below to see for yourself.

Plot Synopsis

A group of high-octane commandos are sent to the jungles of Costa Rica to take out a renegade General Kerensky. Their mission is cut short when they run into a resistance group led by Jack Reacher. The resistance has an ace up their sleeve that proves to be the death of many of the commandos, and in the heat of the battle, one of the commandos is decapitated. This is bad news for the resistance, not only because there are no more guns, but also because Reacher is on the loose and wants revenge. It's up to John McClane (Bruce Willis) and his ragtag motley crew to outflank the bad guys and make their way to the top of the mountain without being gunned down like so many others before them.

At the time, the Taliban controlled 90 percent of Afghanistan, and American forces were under a combat mission of no more than a few months. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Traditional Chinese literary criticism emphasized the life of the author when interpreting a work, a practice which Burton Watson attributes to " the close links that traditional Chinese thought pos
reference_text: its between art and morality ". Since many of Du Fu's poems feature morality and history, this practice is particularly important. Another reason, identified by the Chinese historian William Hung, is that Chinese poems are typically concise, omitting context that might be relevant, but which an informed contemporary could be assumed to know. For modern Western readers, " The less accurately we know the time, the place and the circumstances in the background, the more liable we are to imagine it incorrectly, and the result will be that we either misunderstand the poem or fail to understand it altogether ". Stephen Owen suggests a third factor particular to Du Fu, arguing that the variety of the poet's work required consideration of his whole life, rather than the " reductive " categorizations used for more limited poets.

Burton Watson's research is in the field of China's novel, an increasingly important genre in the 21st century. For more than a decade, he has been conducting ethnographic research in Hong Kong, Macau, and Sichuan to learn about the development of the novel in China and what it means to be a novel in today's China. In this interview, he answers questions about his research and gives his take on the future of the novel in China. We begin by discussing the challenges of working in a non-literary field, and how this has affected his work. reference_text: census of 754 recorded 52 @.@ 9 million people, but ten years later, the census counted just 16 @.@ 9 million, the remainder having been displaced or killed. This period of unhappiness was the making of Du Fu as a poet : Even Shan Chou has written that, " What he saw around him — the lives of his family, neighbors, and strangers – what he heard, and what he hoped for or feared from the progress of various campaigns — these became the enduring themes of his poetry ". According to legend, it was Chang 'an who wrote the treatise on benevolence, known as the Dao De Jing, which laid the foundations of Taoism. In modern times, there is a statue of him in the Hall of Remembrance in the Forbidden City.


As an official, Chang 'an had the rank of Marquis of Hubei, and was one of the most powerful men in the Tang dynasty. He played a key role in the defence of the Tang dynasty against the invasions of the Jurchens, Mongols and Manchus. At the end of the Tang dynasty, he went on to become a patron of the arts and helped to set up the court of the Grand Concubine Huizong (reigned 718-724).

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Du Fu's work is notable above all for its range. Chinese critics traditionally used the term 集大成 ( jídàch
reference_text: éng- " complete symphony " ), a reference to Mencius'description of Confucius. Yuan Zhen was the first to note the breadth of Du Fu's achievement, writing in 813 that his predecessor, " united in his work traits which previous men had displayed only singly ". He mastered all the forms of Chinese poetry : Chou says that in every form he " either made outstanding advances or contributed outstanding examples ". Furthermore, his poems use a wide range of registers, from the direct and colloquial to the allusive and self @-@ consciously literary. This variety is manifested even within individual works : Owen identifies the, " rapid stylistic and thematic shifts " in poems which enable the poet to represent different facets of a situation, while Chou uses the term " juxtaposition " as the major analytical tool in her work. Du Fu is noted for having written more on poetics and painting than any other writer of his time. He wrote eighteen poems on painting alone, more than any other Tang poet. Du Fu's seemingly negative commentary on the prized horse paintings of Han Gan ignited a controversy that has persisted to the present day.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> It was in the 11th century, during the Northern Song era that Du Fu's reputation reached its peak. In this period a comprehensive re @-
reference_text: @ evaluation of earlier poets took place, in which Wang Wei, Li Bai and Du Fu came to be regarded as representing respectively the Buddhist, Daoist and Confucian strands of Chinese culture. At the same time, the development of Neo @-@ Confucianism ensured that Du Fu, as its poetic exemplar, occupied the paramount position. Su Shi famously expressed this reasoning when he wrote that Du Fu was " preeminent... because... through all his vicissitudes, he never for the space of a meal forgot his sovereign ". His influence was helped by his ability to reconcile apparent opposites : political conservatives were attracted by his loyalty to the established order, while political radicals embraced his concern for the poor. Literary conservatives could look to his technical mastery, while literary radicals were inspired by his innovations. Since the establishment of the People's Republic of China, Du Fu's loyalty to the state and concern for the poor have been interpreted as embryonic nationalism and socialism, and he has been praised for his use of simple, " people's language ".

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Until the 13th century, the Japanese preferred Bai Juyi above all poets and there were few references to Du Fu, although his influence can be seen
reference_text: in some kanshi ( " Chinese poetry made by Japanese poets " ) anthologies such as Bunka Shūreishū in the 9th century. The first notable Japanese appreciator of Du Fu's poetry was Kokan Shiren ( 1278 – 1346 ), a Rinzai Zen patriarch and one of the most prominent authors of the literature of the Five Mountains ; he highly praised Du Fu and made a commentary on some poems of Du Fu from the perspective of a Zen priest in Vol. 11 of Saihokushū. His student Chūgan Engetsu composed many kanshi which were clearly stated " influenced by Du Fu " in their prefaces. Chūgan's student Gidō Shūshin had close connection with the Court and Ashikaga Shogunate and propagated Du Fu's poetry in the mundane world ; one day Nijō Yoshimoto, the Kampaku regent of the Court and the highest authority of renga poetry, asked Gidō, " Should I learn the poetry of Du Fu and Li Bai? " Gidō dared to reply, " Yes if you do have enough capability. No if do not. " Since then, there had been many seminars on Du Fu's poetry both in Zen temples and in the aristocratic society, and as a result his poetry was often cited in Japanese literature in the Muromachi period, e.g., Taiheiki, a historical epic in the late 14th century, and some noh plays such as Hyakuman, Bashō, and Shunkan.

Bai Juyi was born in a well-to-do family in Shizuoka Prefecture in the 1st century bce. He studied at the court of the Emperor Taizong for two years before moving to Edo (present-day Tokyo) to become a court poet. During his time in Edo, he fell in love with a concubine with whom he had a son. The marriage was annulled on the grounds of incompatibility, and this created a rift between Bai Juyi and his son. In an attempt to mend the rift, Bai Juyi began to write poetry, which was received with mixed reviews. It was not until the death of the Emperor Huanghong in 1279 that Bai Juyi was able to rekindle his love affair with his son-in-law. By this time, Du Fu had made his way to Kamakura, and, inspired by the poet's poetry, set out to establish himself as a poet of his own. As a result, he won the favor of the empress Dowager Hezŏn, who gave him a stipend of 100,000 taels of silken cloth every year. This was the first of many stipends that Du Fu would receive for his poetry.

Matsuo Bashō, the greatest haiku poet, was also strongly influenced by Du Fu ; in Oku no Hosomichi, his masterpiece, he cites the first two lines of A Spring View ( 春望 ) before a haiku as its introduction and also many of his other haiku have similar wording and themes. It is said that when he died in Osaka during a long travel, a copy of Du Fu's poetry was found with him as one of a few precious items which he was able to carry around.

Biography

Shào Chuán was born in 1598 or 1599; according to some sources, he was born in Nanchang, Jiangxi Province. At the age of twenty-one, he began to write poetry and poetry anthologies. These work took him to the court of the Marquis of Poyang, which was his home for the next twenty years. During this time, he received a doctorate in philology from the University of Hefei as well as a Ph.D. in linguistics from the University of Wuhan. It is unclear which of these degrees was his master's degree. The most likely explanation is that he received both degrees in the same year. This would make him the first literate person to receive a Ph.D. in two different fields of study.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> A variety of styles have been used in efforts to translate Du Fu's work into English. As Burton Watson remarks in The Selected Poems of Du Fu
reference_text: , " There are many different ways to approach the problems involved in translating Du Fu, which is why we need as many different translations as possible " ( p. xxii ). The translators have had to contend with bringing out the formal constraints of the original without sounding laboured to a Western ear ( particularly when translating regulated verse, or lǜshi ), and accommodating the complex allusions contained particularly in the later works ( Hawkes writes that " his poems do not as a rule come through very well in translation " — p. ix ). One extreme on each issue is represented by Kenneth Rexroth's One Hundred Poems From the Chinese. His are free translations, which seek to conceal the parallelisms through enjambement and expansion and contraction of the content ; his responses to the allusions are firstly to omit most of these poems from his selection, and secondly to " translate out " the references in those works which he does select.

This is an important point, inasmuch as translation is a work of art, and it is the translator's responsibility to make the work he or she is translating fit for the audience in which it is to be read.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Despite the expensive reconstructions, both vessels were considered obsolete by the eve of the Pacific War, and neither saw significant action in the early years of the war
reference_text: . Following the loss of most of the IJN's large aircraft carriers during the Battle of Midway in mid @-@ 1942, they were rebuilt with a flight deck replacing the rear pair of gun turrets to give them the ability to operate an air group of floatplanes. A lack of aircraft and qualified pilots, however, meant that they never actually operated their aircraft in combat. While awaiting their air group the sister ships were sometimes used to ferry troops and material to Japanese bases. They participated in the Battle of Cape Engaño in late 1944, where they decoyed the American carrier fleet supporting the invasion of Leyte away from the landing beaches. Afterwards both ships were transferred to Southeast Asia ; in early 1945 they participated in Operation Kita, where they transported petrol and other strategic materials to Japan. The sisters were then reduced to reserve until they were sunk during American airstrikes in July. After the war they were scrapped in 1946 – 47.

History Edit

Origins Edit

The design of the Dauntless was an amalgamation of designs dating back to the 18th century. One of the earliest mentions of a battleship was in the Treaty of Versailles in 1815, which stipulated that France would be responsible for building at least one "armored frigate" for the United States. This led to the construction of the Royal Navy's first-ever warship, the Dreadnought Charles Napier, in 1817. However, the Navy was short on frigates at the time, and Charles Napier was decommissioned two years later for not being seaworthy. [1]

As a result, the Admiralty set about procuring a new warship that would be capable of fighting in the North Atlantic and Indian Oceans. On the other hand, naval construction had reached a standstill due to the Civil War, and there was no money to be made in shipbuilding. This was the impetus for the Navy to re-examine the possibilities of construction of a fleet-defenseless battleship. By 1820, Sir Humphrey Gilbert, a well-

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> In the aftermath, the Japanese Empire immediately turned its focus to the two remaining rivals for imperial dominance in the Pacific Ocean : Britain and the United States. Sat
reference_text: ō Tetsutarō, a Japanese Navy admiral and military theorist, speculated that conflict would inevitably arise between Japan and at least one of its two main rivals. To that end, he called for the Japanese Navy to maintain a fleet with at least 70 % as many capital ships as the US Navy. This ratio, Satō theorized, would enable the Imperial Japanese Navy to defeat the US Navy in one major battle in Japanese waters in any eventual conflict. Accordingly, the 1907 Imperial Defence Policy called for the construction of a battle fleet of eight modern battleships, 20 @,@ 000 long tons ( 20 @,@ 321 t ) each, and eight modern armoured cruisers, 18 @,@ 000 long tons ( 18 @,@ 289 t ) each. This was the genesis of the Eight @-@ Eight Fleet Program, the development of a cohesive battle line of sixteen capital ships.

edit] Trivia

Clan Hell's name is a reference to the "Three Musketeers" by Alexandre Dumas.

See also [ edit ]Image copyright Thinkstock Image caption An artist's impression of the asteroid heading towards Earth

A team of scientists has made a breakthrough in the search for life on other planets.

Astronomers have known for some time that comets are rich in organics, but it has been difficult to work out what they are made of.

Now, using data from Rosetta, a probe orbiting the comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko, the work has been published in Nature.

It is the first time this "fingerprint" has been made to a comet's surface.

Comets are fascinating for lots of reasons, not the least of which is their habit of delivering water to the inner Solar System.

But we also know that there are a lot of craters on them, which is a tell-tale sign of a collision with another body.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The progress of Fusō's construction, while the IJN waited for the funding to be released and foreign developments, caused the IJN
reference_text: to reassess the Fusō @-@ class design. The distribution of the midships gun turrets was the most obvious flaw as they complicated the protection of the midships magazine and exposed more of the ship to the blast effects of the guns when they fired. Another issue was that Japanese sailors had problems maintaining a high rate of fire with the 45 @.@ 36 @-@ kilogram ( 100 @.@ 0 lb ) shells used in the manually loaded 152 @-@ millimetre ( 6 in ) secondary guns used in the Fusō class and earlier designs. To resolve this issue, the IJN designed a smaller 140 @-@ millimetre ( 5 @.@ 5 in ) gun that offset its lighter shell weight with a higher rate of fire. It also decided that the barbette armour of the earlier ships was too thin and wanted a modest increase in speed to partially counter the higher speeds of the latest foreign ships like the British Queen Elizabeth @-@ class battleships and Russian Borodino @-@ class battlecruisers. For financial reasons more powerful engines could not be ordered so the new design was lengthened slightly and the boiler rooms enlarged to increase speed by 0 @.@ 5 knots ( 0 @.@ 93 km / h ; 0 @.@ 58 mph ) to 23 knots ( 43 km / h ; 26 mph ). To save weight the forecastle deck was shortened so that the lower midships gun turret was lower than in the Fusō class. This reduced the crew's accommodations despite a significant increase in the crew's numbers and naval historian Fukui Shizuo believed that these ships had the worst habitability of any Japanese capital ship. The final design was designated A @-@ 92 by the IJN and differed enough from the A @-@ 64 design of the Fusō class that it was considered a separate class.

Battle of Midway (1941) Edit

At the Battle of Midway in World War II, the U.S.S. Hornet was shot down by Zero and crash-landed on Takao Island. During the battle, the Hornet suffered heavy damage to its superstructure, resulting in the loss of all power and navigational equipment. This, combined with the crew's inexperience in piloting a ship of this size, led to the ship's destruction. (LOGH: 'Midway's Finest')

As mentioned last time, the thickness of the armour plating is dependent on the calibre of the gun in question. In other words, the higher the calibre, the thicker the armour will be. This is one of the reasons why tank destroyers are able to get through armour-piercing shells without so much as a scratch. For those of you who do not know, there are two types of armour that can be penetrated by shell: homogeneous armour (HVAR) and sloped armour (SAHAR). HV

External link EditImage copyright Thinkstock Image caption An artist's impression of the Enceladus probe in orbit around Saturn

Saturn's moon Enceladus is teeming with geysers spewing water vapour and hydrocarbons into space, scientists say.

The Cassini probe has flown by the moon more than 20 times since arriving in 2004.

This latest flyby, at a distance of 1,200km (746 miles), provides the clearest evidence yet that plumes of water-vapour are a regular feature of the surface.

There is no sign of subsurface ice to account for the eruptions.

Dr Alan Stern, from the Southwest Research Institute in Boulder, Colorado, told BBC News: "We were astounded to see so many erupting fountains on Enceladus.

"What's going on is an active geyser system that spews water and ethane [a hydrocarbon] all over the surface like a bathtub at the end of the day."

At the end of the war the Mk.V had a range of 4,000 yards and could fire up to 12,000 rounds per minute. This equates to an average rate of fire of one round every 2.5 seconds. In other words, it was the most accurate anti-aircraft gun in the world when you consider the time it took to reload the gun and take a shot.


There were a number of factors that contributed to the design of the Mk.V, none of which were good. First, the gun was designed to be light and maneuverable, a task that was easy to accomplish with the weight of the gun and the ease of maneuvering over sand dunes. As a result, the gun did not have the armor that was required for long range defense. This in turn resulted in a high rate of fire at close range, not the best for a battle tank. Another problem was the ammunition. All weapons have a trade off between damage and lethality. The M1917A1 had a muzzle velocity of 1,890 feet per second (fps) and a cyclic rate of 1,000 rounds per minute (rpm). The design was based on the experience gained during the World War II and post-war shipbuilding programs. It was an all-welded belt made of high-strength steels and laminated at the waterline to prevent fraying. There were two types of belt: 1) a "floating" belt in which the rivets were fastened to the belt; and 2) a "cradled" belt in which the rivets were welded to the belt. The belt was designed to be watertight, but this was not a requirement due to the weight of the ship. As a result, the belt was susceptible to punctures and water ingress. In any case, such damage was of little consequence to the ship, which was protected by the belt.


The Ise @-@ class, along with the Akizuki Maru, were the first battleships to be fitted with anti-torpedo bulges under the waterline. These were located in the keel and served as stabilizers for the superstructure. They were removed in the mid-1950s and replaced by more modern, self-sealing air-intake sluices.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Ise class were the only Japanese battleships to place the powder magazine above the shell magazine as the IJN wished to put as much space as
reference_text: possible between the highly flammable propellant and mine and torpedo detonations. The danger from plunging shells at long distances was not appreciated until the fatal magazine explosions of three British battlecruisers during the 1916 Battle of Jutland graphically demonstrated the point. To further protect the magazines the depth of the double bottom was increased to a total of 3 @.@ 58 metres ( 11 ft 9 in ) underneath the barbettes and magazines. Additionally, the vessels contained 660 watertight compartments to preserve buoyancy in the event of battle damage. In addition to the torpedo bulge added when the ships were modernized, the deck armour over the machinery and magazines was increased to a total thickness of 140 mm. Inside the original skin of the ships, two torpedo bulkheads were also added and the turret roofs were increased to a total of 152 millimetres ( 6 in ) of armour.

One of the problems with the ship was that there was no air tight seal between the powder magazine and the shell magazine. This had the effect of allowing condensation to build up in the powder magazine, which in turn led to overheating during periods of heavy fire. I'm not sure if this was intentional or not, but it was an unfortunate side effect of the design.


After World War II, the United States of America took over the decommissioned ships and refitted them with U.S. Navy ordnance. Some of the modifications were carried out retroactively, such as the addition of anti-torpedo bulges to the superstructure. These bulges were intended to counter the damage caused by torpedoes, but did little to help the survivability of the ship. As a result, the USS Saratoga was re-designated the USS Nautilus in the 1950s. This name was taken from the mythological creature that dwells in the sea, and is able to change its shape at will. The Nautilus has a hull made of polycarbonate, rather than steel, and is powered by a Rolls Royce Neptun engine. Although much smaller than the IJN Nagato, the Nautilus is capable of carrying a much larger complement of armament, including nuclear

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The sinking of the British capital ships Prince of Wales and Repulse by Japanese land @-@ based aircraft on 10 December 1941 led the IJN to
reference_text: realize that battleships could not operate in the face of enemy aircraft and required friendly air support to protect them. The loss of four Japanese aircraft carriers during the Battle of Midway in June 1942 severely limited the ability of the IJN to provide any air cover and alternatives were sought. Earlier proposals to convert one or more battleships into carriers had been made and rejected at the beginning of the war, but they were revived after Midway. Plans for more elaborate conversions were rejected on the grounds of expense and, most critically, time, and the IJN settled on removing the rear pair of turrets and replacing them with a flight deck equipped with two catapults to launch floatplanes. The Ise @-@ class ships were selected for the conversion because Hyūga had suffered an explosion in Turret No. 5 in early May that virtually destroyed the turret and their Turret No. 6 could not elevate to the full + 43 degrees deemed necessary for the long @-@ range engagement anticipated by the IJN. The Fusōs were scheduled to follow once the first two were completed.

As a result, the Navy had to improvise on the hoof and, within a few months, was able to put to sea at full strength.

Origins Edit

The idea of a carrier-based anti-aircraft (AA) unit was a long-standing one in the United States Navy, dating back to the mid-19th century. One of the most famous examples of this was the U.S. Navy's Battleship Potemkin, which saw service in the Russo-Japanese War of 1904-05 and World War I. However, the type did not see widespread use until the Second World War, when the Royal Navy (R.N.) began to look for a replacement for cruisers and destroyers, in addition to aircraft carriers. At the same time, the Soviet Union was making a push into the Pacific, and saw the need for a carrier-based AA unit as well. It was this that led to the creation of the Zvezda (Звезда, Severnaya) class of battleships, which were armed with long-range torpedoes and machine guns for AA defense. By the time the war ended, the Zvezda had been superseded by the Akula (Акула

Ammunition is one of the most important factors in the survivability of a ship. This is due to the fact that it is the fuel that powers the propellers and provides the power to move the ship from one place to another. To this end, torpedoes and depth charges are a must, as well as machine guns and howitzers. These weapons come in all shapes and sizes, and there are no two that are alike. Each and every one of them has a range, damage per salvo, and fire rate that is suited to the task at hand. For example, a.50 caliber machine gun at 100 yards will do more damage than a high explosive (HE) shell at the same range. The difference is one of time of flight, in other words, how long it takes the shell to reach its target. HE shells travel at a speed of 1,000 feet per second, while subsonic (under Mach 1) or supersonic (over Mach 1) are more maneuverable and have a higher rate of fire. When deciding on the type of weapon to use, it is important to consider the following: Range of the

Before the start of the Pacific War, both ships frequently exercised off the coasts of the Soviet Union, Korea and China in addition to training in Japanese waters. Ise hosted Edward, Prince of Wales, and his aide @-@ de @-@ camp Lieutenant Louis Mountbatten in 1922 during the prince's visit to Japan. In Korea Bay when the 1923 Great Kantō earthquake struck, they sailed to Kyushu where they loaded supplies from for the victims on 4 September. Together with two other battleships and a pair of light cruisers, Ise sank the destroyer Yayoi in 1926 during gunnery practice. Ise's AA armament was upgraded in 1931 and Hyūga's two years later. The latter ship was modernized in 1934 – 36 and Ise in 1935 – 37, both at Kure Naval Arsenal. During the Second Sino @-@ Japanese War, the sisters frequently patrolled the Chinese coast in support of the blockade imposed by Japan. In August 1937 Hyūga ferried two battalions of Special Naval Landing Forces to Port Arthur. Three years later, she served as the flagship for the Emperor of the puppet state of Manchukuo, Henry Pu @-@ yi, during his state visit to Japan in June 1940. On 15 November the ships were transferred to the 2nd Battleship Division of the 1st Fleet. The sisters were refitted in late 1940 in preparation for war, which included the fitting of external degaussing coils and additional AA directors.

AMY GOODMAN: We turn now to North Carolina, where Governor Pat McCrory signed a bill banning transgender people from using bathrooms that match their gender identity. The law takes effect July 1st. Critics say it discriminates against the LGBT community at a time when the United States is dealing with a surge in hate crimes—hundreds of trans people have been murdered this year alone. The Japanese plan for the defence of the Philippines envisioned that the surviving carriers would be used to lure the American carrier forces away from the invasion area to a position where the carriers could be attacked by land @-@ based aircraft and the transports by the rest of the IJN. The other carrier air groups were not in much better shape and the Japanese decided to retain the aircraft ashore for use against the American carriers. The Fourth Carrier Division was assigned to the Northern Force under the command of Vice Admiral Jisaburō Ozawa and the sisters sailed from Yashima on 20 October. On the morning of 24 October, the bulk of the few aircraft aboard were launched to attack the American carriers as a distraction. They inflicted no damage and caused the Americans to search in the direction from which they had attacked. The Americans finally spotted the Japanese carriers at 16 : 40, some 200 miles ( 320 km ) east of Cape Engaño, the northeastern tip of Luzon. The American carriers were spread out and it was very late in the day to launch an airstrike, so Admiral William Halsey, commander of the Third Fleet decided to mass his carriers in a position to attack the following morning. Ozawa reversed course during the night, correctly believing that the Americans would follow him north.

June 1, 1942. It was decided to move the training to Pensacola, Florida in order to avoid oversupply of aircrew and maintain a supply of aircraft that could be used in the event of a war with Japan.


Pensacola Naval Air Station was established on a 100 acre tract of land north of Fernandina Beach, Florida (map courtesy of U.S. Naval Historical Center). The Navy began construction of the air station in the summer of 1942 and it was completed in time for Operation Crossroads that summer. As early as 1942, plans were in place to train as many as 1,000 pilots a year at Pensacola. This did not come to pass due to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in December 1941, which brought the United States into World War II. After the war, there was a lot of debate about the advisability of reopening the training to combat pilots. Some felt that it would be unwise to take too many risk and risk the lives of men who were in the process of becoming combat pilots. Others felt that the time was not propitious to do so. In any event, the decision was made to discontinue the training and focus on more important matters.


Aerial view of Pensacola Naval Air Station looking south (courtesy of Chris Kennedy).

Russian Admiral Grigorovich Ushakov took part in the Operation Medusa-Flotilla, which aimed to break the blockade of Luzon (Philippines) by the Japanese Maritime Self-Defense Force (JMSDF). At the end of World War II, the United States of America (USA) and the Soviet Union (USSR) signed the San Francisco Peace Treaty in which they agreed to stop hostilities on each other's territories. This was the first time in 20 years that the two superpowers did not fight a war.

Admiral Ushakov's task was to sail the battleship Ise Maru (IMO: 9062051) from Vladivostok to Subic Bay, Philippines, in order to deliver war materiel to the troops fighting in the Philippines. After a stop was made en route, the admiral made his way to Tacloban in the Philippines as part of the relief effort after Typhoon Haiyan (international name: Yolanda) wreaked havoc on the archipelago.

Early life and career Edit

Gale was born in St. Louis, Missouri, to Mildred (née Flemming) and the late Dr. Richard Gale. His father was a high school teacher and his mother worked as a homemaker. At the age of six, he moved with his mother to New York City, where he attended Roosevelt High School. In his senior year, he earned a scholarship to West Point, where he graduated in the top 10 percent of his class. Upon graduation, he was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the United States Army Air Corps (USAAF, pronounced "Ack-truh-fiss" in the phonetic alphabet that was used at the time to transcribe military orders, e.g. "We are going to drop napalm on the Viet Cong, do you understand?"). The war ended in 1973, and shortly after his enlistment was up, he began his broadcasting career as a sportscaster for KTLA-TV in Los Angeles. [1] (X)

Hurricane Irene in 2011 ranks as the #1 most intense Atlantic hurricane of all time, with a wind speed of 185 mph (295 km/h). However, there is no record of a hurricane making landfall in Florida, much less destroying the state of Florida. That distinction belongs to Hurricane Agnes in 1851, which left a trail of destruction up and down the East Coast of the United States, as well as Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

Irene has been reclassified as a Category 1 hurricane, which means it has sustained winds of at least 111 mph (185 km/h; 72 mph in the Carolinas/Georgia coastal region). In that category, Irene would have been equal to today's supertyphoon Haiyan, which devastated the Philippines last year.

Haiyan (international name: Yolanda) killed more than 6,000 people and caused billions of dollars in damage before it was downgraded to a tropical storm. Hurricane Ophelia is the name given to the category 3 storm that made landfall in Ireland on Wednesday with winds of up to 130 km/h (80 mph). At least one person has died, and thousands of homes were without power.

What is it?

Ophelia is a subtropical cyclone, meaning it is located in the tropics. This type of storm is associated with warm ocean breezes that lead to thunderstorms and tornadoes.

How strong is it?

In the Atlantic Ocean, hurricanes are classified as Category 3 or higher. According to the National Hurricane Center, Ophelia is expected to remain a Category 3 storm for the next 48 hours.

Why is it called Ophelia?

Some meteorologists were perplexed by the name, which is Greek for "victory" or "heavenly deliverance." In an interview with Weather.com, NHC meteorologist Evan Duffey said his opinion was that the name was chosen to symbolize the end of the Roman Empire, which lasted from 410 to 337 B.C.

Are there other names for hurricanes?

Yes. For example, one of the most famous hurricanes in history is Andrew, which killed more than 1,000 people in the Indian Ocean in 1992. Another well-known hurricane is Katia

A station there reported a pressure of 27 @.@ 98 inHg ( 948 mb ) during a 40 minute period of the eye's passage ; this suggested a landfall strength of 125 mph ( 201 km / h ). At the time, the radius of maximum winds was 15 mi ( 24 km ), which was smaller than average. After landfall, the hurricane weakened rapidly while crossing the state. It briefly emerged into the Gulf of Mexico as a tropical storm early on September 5. A few hours later while continuing to the northwest, it made another landfall near Rosewood — a ghost town in Levy County, east of Cedar Key — with winds of about 65 mph ( 105 km / h ). Turning to the north, the storm slowly weakened as it crossed into Georgia, dissipating on September 7 near Augusta.

Hurricanes are cyclonic storms that form over warm water (tropical or subtropical) and lose their tropical characteristics as they move toward land. This is known as the eyewall, and it is the point of maximum intensification of the storm. At the eyewall, winds reach up to 200 mph (322 km/h) and gusts of up to 315 mph (566 km/h). Wind shear (difference in wind speed between the surface and the air above it) is a function of the square of the distance from the equator in a clockwise direction. As the storm moves toward land, the wind shear increases, and the storm becomes more likely to produce tornadoes.

There are three types of hurricanes: tropical, extratropical, and extratropical depression. Tropical depressions are the most intense category of hurricanes, with winds in excess of 185 mph (295 km/h). Subtropical depressions are similar to tropical depressions, but tend to have winds in excess of 110 mph (177 km/h). Extratropical depressions are characterized by winds in excess of 70 mph (113 km/h). A hurricane is an umbrella term for a group of thunderstorms in the same general area. For

South Yorkshire Police has launched a campaign to warn people about the dangers of drink driving.

Drivers are being urged to look out for road signs warning of the dangers of overindulging after one in five people in the West Yorkshire and Humber region fail to do so.

The campaign, StopDrinkDriving.com, is backed by the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) and alcohol charity Drinkaware.

There were 1,638 drink-driving convictions in the region last year.

Chief Constable Dee Collins said: "Alcohol is a factor in so many road deaths and serious injuries, and we are determined to crack down on this as hard as we can.

"That's why we set out to find a way to get people to think twice before they get behind the wheel and put themselves and others at risk."

reference_text: th century. The ironclad was developed as a result of the vulnerability of wooden warships to explosive or incendiary shells. The first ironclad battleship, Gloire, was launched by the French Navy in November 1859. The British Admiralty had been considering armored warships since 1856 and prepared a draft design for an armored corvette in 1857 ; in early 1859 the Royal Navy started building two iron @-@ hulled armored frigates, and by 1861 had made the decision to move to an all @-@ armored battle fleet. After the first clashes of ironclads ( both with wooden ships and with one another ) took place in 1862 during the American Civil War, it became clear that the ironclad had replaced the unarmored ship of the line as the most powerful warship afloat. This type of ship would come to be very successful in the American Civil War.

History Edit

The most common type of ironclad was the 16-inch (406 mm) barbette, which was the largest and most heavily laden of the ship types. By the 1890s, the size of the barbed earthen barge had increased to a height of at least 18 inches (457 mm) and could carry up to 1,000 tons of cargo. This increase in size necessitated the development of steam-powered ironclads such as the "Dunkerque" at the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805-1806. These steamships were faster and more maneuverable than their barbette forerunners, but suffered from a lack of ballast and, in the event of a collision, were at the mercy of the wind and waves. As a result, there were few if any battleships of this type in service until the Great War.

Modern-day ironclads have come a long way since their heyday. In the mid-20th century, it was common to see a number of steel-hulled, water-skipland-capable ironclads on the U.S. Navy's amphibious task forces. More recently, the Royal Navy has taken to the design of high-speed catamarans for sea trials to see how they stack up against each other in speed and

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The era of the wooden steam ship @-@ of @-@ the @-@ line was brief, because of new, more powerful naval guns.

Then, the first shell guns firing explosive shells were introduced following their development by the French Général Henri @-@ Joseph Paixhans, and by the 1840s were part of the standard armament for naval powers including the French Navy, Royal Navy, Imperial Russian Navy and United States Navy. It is often held that the power of explosive shells to smash wooden hulls, as demonstrated by the Russian destruction of an Ottoman squadron at the Battle of Sinop, spelled the end of the wooden @-@ hulled warship. The more practical threat to wooden ships was from conventional cannon firing red @-@ hot shot, which could lodge in the hull of a wooden ship and cause a fire or ammunition explosion. Some navies even experimented with hollow shot filled with molten metal for extra incendiary power.

In 1805, Lord Milner-Bosworth, a well-known shipbuilder, set about commissioning a warship that would be at the forefront of the battle for supremacy in the North Sea. His design was based on the work of Sir Humphrey Davy, who had come up with the idea of a "marauding sloop" in the 1830s. Milner-Bosworth went one step further, taking into account the advantages of gunnery and manoeuvrability as well as an armour plating of up to 30mm (1.2in) at the waterline. This was more than sufficient to fend off the much larger Napoleonic frigates that were in the Royal Navy's crosshairs.

These were mounted on pylons that jutted out from the keel, and each of the ship's guns had a range of more than two miles (3.2km). By this time, the Union had completed seven ironclad gunboats of the City class, and was about to complete the USS Monitor, an innovative design proposed by the Swedish inventor John Ericsson. In 1864, President Abraham Lincoln signed the Ordinance of Secession, which called for the secession of South Carolina and its seceding states from the Union. At the same time, the Confederates began construction of the Sultana, a battleship that would go on to play a key role in the war. Both ships were powered by steam catapults, an innovation that made them faster and more maneuverable than their iron-hulled predecessors. As early as the summer of 1861, there were murmurs of war between the North and South, but nothing came of it until the latter part of the year. That's when the United States declared war on the Confederate States of America (Confederate States of America, or CSA for short), and it was over in less than a year.

A magma lamp is a light source that radiates magma. Lamps work by melting obsidian, the material used to make weapons and armor. In order to do this, the lamp must be close to a magma sea, such as a volcano or geyser. This is important to keep in mind when dealing with volcanoes, as lava does not flow at 100% efficiency, but at a rate dependent on the temperature of the magma sea. For example, a volcano with a temperature of -1 is capable of producing up to 1.5 liters of lava per second, while a volcano with a temperature of 100 is capable of producing up to 2 liters per second. It is worth noting that these numbers are rounded to the nearest integer, so an unenchanted firelighter (not to be confused with flint and steel) can produce as much lava as a fully energized flaming sword of all material types.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Temnospondyli ( from Greek τέμνειν ( temnein, " to cut " ) and σπ
reference_text: όνδυλος ( spondylos, " vertebra " ) ) is a diverse subclass of extinct small to giant tetrapods — often considered primitive amphibians — that flourished worldwide during the Carboniferous, Permian, and Triassic periods. A few species continued into the Cretaceous. Fossils have been found on every continent. During about 210 million years of evolutionary history, they adapted to a wide range of habitats, including fresh water, terrestrial, and even coastal marine environments. Their life history is well understood, with fossils known from the larval stage, metamorphosis, and maturity. Most temnospondyls were semiaquatic, although some were almost fully terrestrial, returning to the water only to breed. These temnospondyls were some of the first vertebrates fully adapted to life on land. Although temnospondyls are considered amphibians, many had characteristics, such as scales, claws, and armour @-@ like bony plates, that distinguish them from modern amphibians.

Anatomy and Physiology [ edit ]

A diagram of the trachea and larynx of a cetacean.

Ternospondyli are composed of cartilaginous spines, arranged in concentric ridges (Fig. 1). The most distal of these spines is the pharyngeal spindles, which connect to the diaphragm and vocal cords. The proximal pharyngeal spindles are known as ossicones, and the distal ones are known as palatine spines. There are at least three types of osseous spines: 1) epiglottis, 2) sclerotized, and 3) unsecreting. The epiglottis is a series of soft papillae that enclose the windpipe during respiration. The sclerotized spines are similar to the epiglottis in that they encircle the windpipe, but they are covered with keratin filaments rather than epithelium. The unsecreting spines are found in the esophagus, duodenum

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Many temnospondyls are much larger than living amphibians, and superficially resemble crocodiles. Others are smaller and resemble salamanders
reference_text: . Most have broad, flat heads that are either blunt ( brevirostrine ) or elongated ( longirostrine ). The skulls are rounded or triangular in shape when viewed from above, and are usually covered in pits and ridges. The rugged surfaces of bones may have supported blood vessels, which could transfer carbon dioxide to the bones to neutralize acidic build up in the blood ( early semiaquatic tetrapods would have had difficulty expelling carbon dioxide from their bodies while on land, and these dermal bones may have been an early solution to the problem ). Many temnospondyls also have canal @-@ like grooves in their skulls called sensory sulci. The sulci, which usually run around the nostrils and eye sockets, are part of a lateral line system used to detect vibrations in water. As semiaquatic animals, most temnospondyls have small limbs with four toes on each front foot and five on each hind foot. Terrestrial temnospondyls have larger, thicker limbs, and some even have claws. One unusual terrestrial temnospondyl, Fayella, has relatively long limbs for its body, and probably lived as an active runner able to chase prey.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Homologues of most of the bones of temnospondyls are also seen in other early tetrapods, aside from a few bones in
reference_text: the skull, such as interfrontals, internasals, and interparietals, that have developed in some temnospondyl taxa. Most temnospondyls have tabular horns in the backs of their skulls, rounded projections of bone separated from the rest of the skull by indentations called otic notches ; in some temnospondyls, such as Zatrachys, they are pointed and very prominent. Among the most distinguishing features of temnospondyls are the interpterygoid vacuities, two large holes in the back of the palate. Another pair of holes, choanae, are present in front of these vacuities, and connect the nasal passage with the mouth. Temnospondyls often have teeth on their palates, as well as in their jaws. Some of these teeth are so large, they are referred to as tusks. In some temnospondyls, such as Nigerpeton, tusks in the lower jaw pierce the palate and emerge through openings in the top of the skull.

Rather, they are homologous with the bony integument of the plastron, which is composed of keratin filaments interwoven with lamellar trabeculae to form connective tissue. There is no evidence for fusion of the fibrous integument with the cartilaginous skeleton, such as occurs in crocodilians and pangolins. As far as we know, the bone histology of placoderm-dwelling amphibians is the same as that of metazoans, in which the epidermis overlies the dermis and subcutaneous stratum corneum.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Several groups of temnospondyls have large bony plates on their backs. One temnospondyl, Peltobatrachus
reference_text: , has armour @-@ like plating that covers both its back and underside. The temnospondyl Laidleria also has extensive plating on its back. Most members of the family Dissorophidae also have armor, although it only covers the midline of the back with two narrow rows of plates. Other temnospondyls, such as Eryops, have been found with small, disc @-@ like bony scutes that were in life probably embedded in the skin. All of these temnospondyls were adapted to a terrestrial lifestyle. Armor may have offered protection from predators in the case of Peltobatrachus. The scutes may have provided stability for the spine, as they would have limited flexibility and may have been connected by strong ligaments. Temnospondyls such as Sclerothorax and Eryops that may have been at least partly terrestrial also have long neural spines on top of their vertebrae that would have stabilized the spine. Bony scutes are also seen in plagiosaurs, but unlike Peltobatrachus, Laidleria, Eryops, and dissorophids, these animals are thought to have been fully aquatic. Plagiosaurs may have inherited their armor from a terrestrial ancestor, as both Peltobatrachus and Laidleria have been considered close relatives of the group.

What's the difference between arboreal and terrestrial temnospondyls?

Terrestrial temnospondyls are found in temperate and tropical regions. Arboreal temnospondyls are found in subtropical and tropical regions. There are at least two genera of arboreal temnospondyls: Acomycetes and Pseudotemnospondylus. The most common arboreal temnospondyls are Pseudotemnospondylus spp. and Acomycetes californicus.

How do arboreal temnospondyls get their fur?

Arboreal temnospondyls spend most of their time on the ground. This is because it is hard to burrow into the ground and maintain a body temperature above 32°C (90°F). As a result, arboreal temnospondyls rely on their fur to keep them warm. Fur is made up of keratin, a protein that is similar to fingernails and hair. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Temnospondyls'vertebrae are divided into several segments. In living tetrapods, the main body of the vertebra is a
reference_text: single piece of bone called the centrum, but in temnospondyls, this region was divided into a pleurocentrum and intercentrum. Two types of vertebrae are recognized in temnospondyls : stereospondylous and rhachitomous vertebrae. In rhachitomous vertebrae, the intercentra are large and wedge @-@ shaped, and the pleurocentra are relatively small blocks that fit between them. Both elements support a spine @-@ like neural arch, and well @-@ developed interlocking projections called zygapophyses strengthen the connections between vertebrae. The strong backbone and strong limbs of many ratchitomous temnospondyls allowed them to be partially, and in some cases fully, terrestrial. In stereospondylous vertebrae, the pleurocentra have been lost entirely, with the intercentra enlarged as the main body of the vertebrae. This weaker type of backbone indicates the stereospondylous temnospondyls spent more time in water.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Mastodonsaurus and other similar animals were referred to as labyrinthodonts, named like Labyrinthodon for teeth that were highly folded in cross section.
reference_text: Owen's " Labyrinthodon Jaegeri " was later found at Guy's Cliffe, England by paleontologist William Buckland. Other specimens were found in the red sandstone of Warwickshire. As more fossils were uncovered in England, Owen depicted these labyrinthodonts as the " highest " form of batrachian and compared them to crocodiles, which he considered the highest form of reptiles. He also noted the large labyrinthodonts of the Keuper ( a unit of rocks that dates to the Late Triassic ) were younger than more advanced reptiles in the Magnesian and Zechstein, which are Late Permian in age. Owen used these fossils to counter the notion that reptiles evolved from a sequential progression from early amphibians ( what he called " metamorphosed fishes " ).

Fossils of C. schreibersii from the Maastrichtian (Mamenchisaurus spelae) provide evidence for a change in cranial morphology that took place during the course of metamorphosis. Here we report the discovery of a previously unrecognized postcranial appendage (posterior ramus) in ca. 220 Ma of the holotype of C. schreibersii by synchrotron X-ray computed tomography (CT-XRD). The appendage is similar in cross-section to the laterally compressed humerus of Tyrannosaurus rex, but does not appear to be bony in nature. Rather, it is composed of fibrous connective tissue, as well as keratin filaments extending proximally from the distal end of the ramus. An anatomically and phylogenetically plausible origin for the palatine articulation is suggested by the morphological similarity of the Ramus posterolaterally and medially, and the fact that the latter has been tentatively assigned to the articular surface of the tibia.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Originally, temnospondyls were classified according to the structure of their vertebrae. Early forms, with complex vertebrae consisting of a
reference_text: number of separate elements, were placed in the suborder Rachitomi, and large Triassic aquatic forms with simpler vertebrae were placed in the suborder Stereospondyli. With the recent growth of phylogenetics, this classification is no longer viable. The basic rhachitomous condition is found in many primitive tetrapods, and is not unique to one group of temnospondyls. Moreover, the distinction between rhachitomous and stereospondylous vertebrae is not entirely clear. Some temnospondyls have rhachitomous, semirhachitomous, and sterospondylous vertebrae at different points in the same vertebral column. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Recently, the theory that temnospondyls were the ancestors of all lissamphibians has gained wide support. The skull morphology of some
reference_text: small temnospondyls has been compared to those of modern frogs and salamanders, but the presence of bicuspid, pedicellate teeth in small, paedomorphic or immature temnospondyls has been cited as the most convincing argument in favor of the temnospondyl origin of lissamphibians. Seen in lissamphibians and many dissorophoid temnospondyls, pedicellate teeth have calcified tips and bases. During the development of most tetrapods, teeth begin to calcify at their tips. Calcification normally proceeds downward to the base of the tooth, but calcification from the tip stops abruptly in pedicellate teeth. Calcification resumes at the base, leaving an area in the center of the tooth uncalcified. This pattern is seen in living amphibians and fossils.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Most aquatic stereospondyls have flattened heads. When feeding, they probably opened their mouths by lifting their skulls instead of lowering their lower jaws. The
reference_text: jaw mechanics of the plagiosaurid Gerrothorax is well known, and is one of the most highly adapted. Gerrothorax is thought to have lifted its skull to around 50 ° above horizontal through the flexing of the atlanto @-@ occipital joint between the occipital condyles of the skull and the atlas vertebra of the neck. As the skull is raised, the quadrate bone pushes forward and causes the lower jaw to protrude outward. Other stereospondyls probably also lifted their skulls, but they are not as well adapted for such movement. D.M.S. Watson was the first to suggest skull lifting as a means of feeding in temnospondyls. He envisioned that Mastodonsaurus, a much larger temnospondyl than Gerrothorax, was able to make the same movement. Paleontologist A.L. Panchen also supported the idea in 1959, suggesting that Batrachosuchus also fed in this way. At the time it was thought that these temnospondyls lifted their heads with strong jaw muscles, but it is now thought that they used larger muscles in the neck that were attached to the large pectoral girdle. Plagiosuchus, a close relative of Gerrothorax, also has a hyobranchial skeleton that muscles may have attached to. Plagiosuchus has very small teeth and a large area for muscle attachment behind the skull, suggesting that it could suction feed by rapidly opening its mouth.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Temnospondyls, like all amphibians, reproduced in aquatic environments. Most temnospondyls probably reproduced through external fertilization.
reference_text: Like most living frogs, female temnospondyls would have laid masses of eggs in water while males released sperm to fertilize them. Several fossils were described from the Early Permian of Texas in 1998 that may be egg masses of dissorophoid temnospondyls. They were the first known fossils of amphibian eggs. The fossils consist of small disks with thin membranes that are probably vitelline membranes and halo @-@ like areas surrounding them that are most likely mucous coatings. They are attached to plant fossils, suggesting that these temnospondyls laid eggs on aquatic plants much like modern frogs. The mucous membranes show that the eggs were laid by amphibians, not fish ( their eggs lack mucous ), but the type of amphibian that laid them cannot be known because no body fossils are preserved with the eggs. The eggs are thought to be from dissorophoids because they are likely to be close relatives of modern amphibians, and probably had similar reproductive strategies. They are also the most common amphibians from the deposit in which the eggs were found.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Temnospondyls like Sclerocephalus are known from both large adult specimens and small larvae, showing an extreme change in body shape.
reference_text: In these species, the shape and proportions of skull bones change in the early stages of development. The ornamentation on the surface of the skull roof also develops at this time. Small, regularly spaced pits are the first to form, followed by larger ridges. As development continues, the external gills disappear. Small teeth that once covered the palate are lost. The postcranial skeleton does not develop at the same rate as the skull, with ossification ( the replacement of cartilage by bone ) happening more slowly. Vertebrae and limb bones are poorly developed, ribs and fingers are absent in the early stages, and the scapulocoracoid and ischium are entirely absent through most of development. Once maturity is reached, most bones have fully formed and growth rate slows. The bones of some temnospondyls like Dutuitosaurus show growth marks, possibly an indication that growth rate varied with the change in seasons. Fossils of temnospondyls like Metoposaurus and Cheliderpeton show that individuals grew larger past maturity. The oldest individuals usually have more pitting on their skulls with deeper sulci.

Credit: University of Exeter It's a well-known fact that vertebrates such as lizards and crocodilians have a lot of spines on their snouts. But what is it about these 'roly-poly' animals that leads to such a large number of spine-bearing appendages?

New research from the University of Exeter has shed light on the secret, uncovering that there are at least two mechanisms by which roly-poly animals are able to grow so many bony protrusions.

The first is due to the growth of cartilage, which acts as a scaffold for the growth of bone. This, in turn, results in the body becoming stiffer and more bone-like. By contrast, the second mechanism has to do with the ability of osteoblasts, which are cells that take up calcium from the bone, to proliferate at a faster rate than non-osteoblasts. Osteoblasts are responsible for the bulk of the bones in the body, and their rate of proliferation is the key to the increase in bone mass.

Lead researcher Dr Chris Wilkins, Lecturer in Integrative Biology at the University of Exeter, said: "We were surprised to find that not only do bones grow in proportion to the body size of the animal, but that the number of bones goes up with body size. This is something that has been

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> One group of temnospondyls, the Branchiosauridae, is also known from larval specimens. Branchiosaurids like Branchios
reference_text: aurus and Apateon are represented by many fossils preserving skin and external gills. An entire growth series is exhibited in the wide range of sizes among specimens, but the lack of terrestrially adapted adult forms suggests that these temnospondyls were neotenic. Unlike other temnospondyls, their postcranial skeletons developed quickly but were still partly cartilaginous when fully mature. Adults likely had an aquatic lifestyle similar to juveniles. Recently, large specimens of Apateon gracilis were described with adaptations toward a terrestrial lifestyle, indicating that not all branchiosaurs were neotenic.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> While most temnospondyls are aquatic in early stages of life, most metoposaurids appear to have been terrestrial in their juvenile stage
reference_text: . Like other Mesozoic temnospondyls, adult metoposaurids were adapted to a semiaquatic lifestyle. Their bones are not highly developed for movement on land. The cross @-@ sectional thickness of limb bones in adult metoposaurids shows that they could not withstand the stress of terrestrial locomotion. Juvenile individuals have bones that are thick enough to withstand this stress, and could probably move about on land. To maintain a terrestrial lifestyle, a temnospondyl's limb bones would have to thicken with positive allometry, meaning that they would grow at a greater rate than the rest of the body. This is not the case in metoposaurids, meaning that as their bodies grew larger they became less adapted toward a terrestrial lifestyle.

reference_text: drum — or homologous tympanum — to the inner ear. Temnospondyls also have a stapes, which projects into the otic cavity. The stapes likely evolved from the hyomandibula of lobe @-@ finned fishes. The positioning of the stapes and the shape of the otic region suggests that the tympani of temnospondyls and frogs are homologous, but the tympani of these amphibians are no longer considered homologous with the hearing systems of reptiles, birds, and mammals. Therefore, ear structures in temnospondyls were not ancestral to those of all other tetrapods.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The ability of the tympanum and stapes to effectively transmit vibrations is called impedance matching. Early tetrapods like temnospondyls
reference_text: have thick stapes with poor impedance matching, so it is now thought that they were not used for hearing. Instead, these thick stapes may have functioned to support the tissue that covers the otic notch. Early temnospondyls like Dendrerpeton could not hear airborne sound but would have been able to detect vibration in the ground. Later temnospondyls like Doleserpeton had otic regions adapted to hearing. Doleserpeton has a structure in the inner ear called the perilymphatic duct, which is also seen in frogs and is associated with hearing. Its stapes is also a better transmitter of sound. The hearing system of Doleserpeton and related temnospondyls was able to detect airborne sound and may have been ancestral to that of living amphibians.

There are two ways to use the Dvorak technique:

Satellite Imagery

As mentioned above, weather satellites are in constant communication with the ground stations that are responsible for sending the meteorological data to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). NOAA has over 4,000 weather satellites in orbit, and each one is equipped with a high-resolution Doppler radar capable of picking up the motion of the upper atmosphere. This radar data is processed by computer and given to forecasters, who use it to make long-range forecasts. One of the problems with this method is that it is time consuming and takes a lot of data to get a good picture of a storm.

reference_text: -@ resolution satellite imagery and more powerful computers. By the 20th century, there was a well-established science of meteorology that focused on convection, in which heat is transferred from warm air to cold air, and vice versa. One of the most important aspects of convection is the so-called adiabatic lapse rate, which is the rate at which heat is radiated from a source to a thermometer or, in layman's terms, the "temperature in Kelvin" (K). That is, the difference between the temperature of the air at the source and the temperature of the air at the thermometer.

Convection does not occur in a vacuum, of course, and it is a good thing that our atmosphere is rich in water vapor, which acts as a condensing agent. This is the reason why thunderstorms are so common in the tropics and subtropics, where there is a lot of water vapor in the air. However, we have been neglecting to pay attention to the role of water vapor in storm formation for a long time.

We have been able to show that, contrary to widely held beliefs, tropical cyclones are not monolithic entities but vary in intensity from season to season and from location to location. This is in contrast to the view that they are homogeneous (Fig. 1) and have a well-defined track that takes them over the equator and downpours them into the tropics. As a result, it is no longer possible to predict with 100% certainty the intensity of a tropical cyclone, let alone an all-encompassing forecast of the season's weather. For example, one need not be concerned about the intensities of El Niño and La Niña events, but one must be cognizant of the differences in track and intensity between ENSO events and non-ENSO events. Such information is readily available from weather balloons and buoys, but these do not provide information on track and intensity. In addition, satellite altimetry provides an even more up-to-date picture of track and intensity, but it is not available in all latitudes and only for short periods of time.

Kershaw's success was a result of a pitch called a strike by umpire Gene Steratore, which was in the strike zone according to Statcast at the time. The rule stipulates that a pitch must be in the strike zone 90 percent of the time in order to be called a strike. As MLB.com's Mark DeRosa points out, there is no data to go on that tells us how often that rule is obeyed, but it's safe to say that not a lot of pitches are in the strike zone this year.

This is an interesting wrinkle to the strike zone, in that it has been known for a long time that pitchers are trying to get away with too many sliders and curveballs, which are harder to pick up on radar guns. Pitchers have figured out ways to do this by changing their release points, and that's one of the reasons Clayton Kershaw is able to throw so many pitches in the zone.

In any case, Steratore's call on the pitch was the right call, and Kershaw went on to strike out Tony Cruz with a two-strike fastball to end the inning. After that, things got dicey for the Dodgers, as Chris Heisey homered off Hyun-Jin Ryu, leading to a game-tying grand slam by

Indigenous art is the result of a culture that thrives in the arid and unforgiving environment of the western desert. There are no water sources, no grazing pastures, no irrigation ditches to draw water from. The land is parched and scorched by the sun year round. Even the birds do not seem to enjoy the monotony of the desert, as they flit from tree to tree like pigeons at a carnival. For this reason, and many others, life is one of the most difficult things to come by in the desert. It is no wonder that so many have turned to art as a means of expressing their feelings and feelings of self-reliance.


Over the years, the concept of painting in the desert has evolved to include an ever-expanding array of mediums, such as paint, pastels, collage, stencils, watercolors, gouache, etchings, lithographs, metal engravings, ceramics, silk embroidery, hand-embroidered textiles, sandpapery, etc. This diversity of mediums was brought to the forefront in the seventies and eighties, when it became common to see artists working in all of these mediums

Alfred Austin, for example, spent the better part of a decade in the 1892-1893 time period attempting to figure out how to copy the movement of pen and ink as it was done in the 19th century. This was no easy task, as there were no machines of the time that could do it for one hundred percent accuracy. It took several years of tinkering with a typewriter, to no avail. Pound was born in 1874 or 1875, the son of a Quaker family in New York City. He began his education at Stuyvesant High School, where he earned a B.A. in 1892. After graduating summa cum laude, he went to Balliol College, Oxford, to study philology. This did not go well, and he dropped out of the study of philology and took a job as a typist in the Daily Telegraph. The Telegraph was a precursor to the New York Times, and Pound wrote for it for two years. By this time, he had fallen in love with the poetry of Keats, Tennyson, Coleridge, Wordsworth, Rimbaud, Yeats, and T.S. Eliot. These poets "helped[ed] me make sense of the bewildering multiplicity of human experience by drawing me inexorably into the heart of what might be called the poet's dream" (1962, p. xi). Pound's intention was to "provide a guide to the works of the most important painters of the 20th century, in order to bring them to the attention of a wider public than they have hitherto enjoyed." In other words, he wanted to popularize the work of the Impressionists without alienating his admirers. This was no easy task, to say the least. Many of the artists had fallen out of favor with the public at large, and there was no love lost between Pound and Aldington, who resented the artist's attitude toward Cubism and Dada. It was this antagonism that led to the publication of Metamorphosis, which was far from a slam-dunk. For one thing, the art world was in the midst of a period of transition, marked by the growth of avant-garde art as well as post-Impressionism. As a result, much of the discussion centered on the question of what, exactly, was going on in the artist's head when he painted a picture. This in turn raised the question of whether one could draw inferences about the artist's mental state from his art. reference_text: a wealthy heiress from Boston whose brother Abbott Lawrence Lowell was President of Harvard University from 1909 @-@ 1933. She loved Keats and cigars. She was also an enthusiastic champion of literary experiment who was willing to use her money to publish the group. Lowell was determined to change the method of selection from Pound's autocratic editorial attitude to a more democratic manner. This new editorial policy was stated in the Preface to the first anthology to appear under her leadership : " In this new book we have followed a slightly different arrangement to that of our former Anthology. Instead of an arbitrary selection by an editor, each poet has been permitted to represent himself by the work he considers his best, the only stipulation being that it should not yet have appeared in book form. " The outcome was a series of Imagist anthologies under the title Some Imagist Poets. The first of these appeared in 1915, planned and assembled mainly by H.D. and Aldington. Two further issues, both edited by Lowell, were published in 1916 and 1917. These three volumes featured most of the original poets, ( also including imagist poetry by the American poet John Gould Fletcher ), with the exception of Pound, who had tried to persuade her to drop the Imagist name from her publications and who sardonically dubbed this phase of Imagism " Amy @-@ gism. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Weeks before the release of Independiente, Arjona issued a letter raising the issue of his past relationships with recording companies. He revealed the circumstances
reference_text: of his first contract : " a producer, friend of mine, told them [ the record label ] that if they did not sign me in, they won 't sign two artists he had [ at that time ] ". Arjona further explained that he received the " minimum royalty percentage " from his most successful albums. Independiente is Arjona's first independent release through his own label : Metamorfosis, a company he created to refocus his career. The company is presided by Arjona and several friends ( including photographer @-@ director Ricardo Calderón, Universal Music México executive Humberto Calderon and BMG's Miriam Sommerz ), and is based in Miami and Mexico City. Arjona commented that his independence represented compromise more than freedom, stating that " Inside the word'Independent ', even when it sounds like extreme freedom, there's a big amount of compromise and the responsibility of being able to administrate, in the best way possible, such independence ". Billboard notes that, although other groups have released independent albums following contracts with major labels, Arjona is the most important Latin pop artist to do so. Although the album is marketed within the new label, distribution was handled by Warner Music.

In the letter, Arjona writes, "I want to be clear that I am not the kind of person who takes advantage of other people, no matter how much money they give me. There are a lot of things that go on behind the scenes in the music industry that are not for the public's benefit, and I feel it is my responsibility to clear my name as much as possible."

So what's the best way to get to know Independiente? Start with the title track, "Aquí Estamos Días" (Let's Talk About Water). It's a ballad about life's impermanence, an ode to the river that nourishes us every day without ceasing to amaze us with its splendor. There's nothing easy about that song, but the heartrending lyrics speak to the universality of human experience. Listen to it and be uplifted, not downcast.

Next, I'm going to give you my pick for the best song on the album, "Por Ejemplo Solencológico" (Out of the Ordinary Solitude). As someone who grew up in Bogotá, I have a hard time picturing a place that's more inhospitable to songwriters than Colombia. Sure, my home city has a ton of world-class music, but that's no excuse to write your love song in the middle of a war zone. In other words, this song is tough to pin down musically, but not in a bad way. On the contrary, it's one of the most lyrically and sonically complex songs on the album.

On January 18, Cyclone Chapala made landfall in Luzon, Philippines, at 11:00 A.M. local time (GMT +7). Chapala was the strongest typhoon to make landfall in the Western Pacific since Super Typhoon Haiyan (Haiyan) in 2013. According to the IMO, there were 6 people killed, including a 3-year-old child, and over 1,000 homes and other buildings damaged or destroyed. More than 10,000 people were without power as a result of the storm.

Chapala dissipated into the Bay of Bengal the next day, but not before leaving a trail of destruction in its wake. This post will focus on the cyclone's impact on the Visayas and Mindanao.

Impact on Vigan

Vigan has been hit hard by Cyclone Chapala. One of the hardest hit areas was Barangay (village) Iligan, which is located north of Tacloban City. Here, the death toll is expected to rise in the coming days. In addition to landslides, waterlogging, and power outages, damage to rice paddy fields has been reported. It is estimated that at least 300,000 hectares of rice paddy fields have been wiped out.

By Scott Sumner

There are two ways to look at the world: as a zero-sum game or as a multidimensional chessboard. One way is to focus on the short-term effects of climate change, like rising sea levels threatening coastal cities that are home to tens of millions of people. The other way is to pay attention to the long-term effects, like melting ice sheets destabilizing the world's coastlines and contributing to a rise in sea levels that in turn threatens much of the world's low-lying land.

In my view, the most important factor in determining the future of the world is population growth. That's because people are the lifeblood of a world economy, and their consumption of resources (food, energy, etc.) has a direct impact on the rate at which carbon dioxide is released into the atmosphere. For example, if China's population grows by 1.5 percent per year, it will emit as much carbon dioxide as the United States does in a year. By 2040, China's population is expected to

MORAKOT, Philippines (AP) — A typhoon barreled toward the Philippines on its way to central Luzon, prompting evacuations and power outages that shut down air traffic and raised fears of landslides.

The National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council said in a statement there were no reports of casualties or major damage so far, but weather officials warned that parts of Mindanao could be uninhabitable for weeks.

Typhoon Morakot spawned from an area of disturbed weather in the Philippine Sea on July 31. Tracking northwest, favorable conditions allowed for the intensification of the system, which resulted in wind speeds of up to 100 kph (62 mph).

Forecasters said high winds and torrential rains were expected to dump as much as 10 inches (25 centimeters) of rain per hour by mid-afternoon local time (2 p.m. EDT; 1800 GMT) on some parts of the Visayas archipelago that straddles the equator.

More than 100,000 people were ordered to evacuate their homes and at least a dozen aircraft were diverted to pick up stranded fliers. Schools and government offices were closed, and the Metro Manila subway suspended service between Makati and Pasay, the capital of Negros Occidental.

Krovanh is characterized by a well-integrated convective eddy-sheath in the subtropical gyre, which propagates northward along the equatorward-trending Rossby wave front (red contour in Fig. 1). The TDR has an anomalously elongated wind field due to the presence of a low-velocity boundary layer associated with the upper mesoscale tropopause (∼500 mbar) and, to a lesser extent, the stratosphere (∼1,000 mbar). On the time scale of a few hours, the intensity of the cyclonic vorticity is about one-third that of the extratropical storm-surge (ES) model-predicted intensification, as shown by the zonal wind vectors (Supplementary Fig. S1). In contrast, the ESM simulations show a much steeper ramp-up in the intensity of the cyclonic vorticity at the end of the 24-hour period (compare top inset in Fig. 1 with bottom inset in Fig. S2).
